Page Six
Pioneer Women Hold
Membership Lunch
The Tucson Council of Pioneer Women will hold their
annual donor luncheon Jan. 22 at noon in the Terrace Room
of the Pioneer Hotel.
Mrs. Sidney Less, national president of Pioneer Women
will be the principal speaker at the luncheon.
| Center
| Hilites ...
CASTING FOR “Another
Language” by the Center
Drama Group will be held
Jan. 20 at 2 p.m. and 7:30
p.m.
Sandy Rosenthal will di
rect the play by Rose Frank
en.
The Yiddish Drama Work
shop holds workouts Jan. 13-
14 at 10 a.m. and 8 p.m. for
“The Cantor’s Son.” The
trials will be held at the Cen
ter.
• • •
MRS. MARTHA STURDE
VANT has been added to the
Center staff and will conduct
exercise, gymnastic and
modern dance classes.
Mrs. Sturdevant studied at
the Hanya Holm School of
Dance and also did post-grad
uate gymnastic work in Scan
danavian countries. She has
had teaching experience at
Michigan State, Ohio Wesley
an and the Universities of
North Dakota and New Mex
ico. She also served as syn
chronized swimming coach
for the U.S. Oympic team.
• • •
A CLASS in exercise ther
apy for arthritic women
opens Jan. 17 at the Center
health club. Robert Patter
son, a registered physical
therapist, conducts the class.
• • •
A NEW COURSE, “Effi
ciency in Reading,” heads
the list of adult courses for
the spring session at the
Center. The program opens
Jan. 13.
Among the other courses
will be Kadimah Dancers,
Creative Writing Workshop,
Drama Workshop, beginning
and discussion courses in He
brew, sewing classes plus a
full routine of dance classes.
Rishona Pioneer
Rishona Chapter of Pio
neer Women will hold an
Oneg Shabat Jan. 19 at the
home of Mrs. Bess Finkel,
1502 N. Louise.

SATURDAY MORNING MUSICAL CLUB
Temple of Music and Art Theatre
isl 330 So. Scott Ave., Tucson, Arizona
Telephone 623-7491
Mrs. Byron Epstein is gen
eral chairman and Mrs. Dav
id Mishkind is in charge of
reservations. The committee
is made up of Mmes. J. Zev
in, Sidney Nevins, Herbert
Feig, Joseph Finkelstein, Sid
ney Morgan, Arthur Solo
mon, Lester Munday, Harry
Epstein and Miss Evelyn
Thome.
Guests are invited to the
donor and tickets can be pur
chased from Pioneer Women
members.
Mrs. Less also will speak
at services of Cong. Anshei
Israel Jan. 18 at which the
Pioneer Women will be host
esses*
Obituaries
Former Tucsonan Emanuel
Finkelstein died Jan. 2 in Los
Angeles at the age of 53.
He was survived by his
wife, Rita, and a son.
Mr. Finkelstein had been
in the building and real es
tate business in Tucson.
• • •
Lee H. Baum, 62, of 455 S.
Irving, died here Dec. 28. He
was formerly from Cincin
nati.
Survivors include his wife,
Hazel, daughter, Mrs. Mar
jorie Heilbrun and two grand
children.
• • •
Harry Solter, 81, of 3316 E.
First, died here Jan. 4.
Survivors include his wife,
Sarah; a daughter, Mrs. Her
bert Margolis; a son, William
H. Solter; and a sister, Miss
Rose Solter.
o
New Executive
Joins Agency
Robert G. Gols et h has
joined the Jacob C. Fruch
thendler Insurance Agency
as an account executive and
will specialize in Commercial
Lines insurance.
Mr. Golseth is a graduate
of Miami (Ohio) University.
He has lived in Phoenix since
1959 where he was connected
with the Associated Invest
ment Co. Mr. Golseth is mar
ried and is an alumni mem
ber of Beta Theta Pi social
fraternity.

Weddings
. - WSSMM mu i
Susan Ilene Lavine became
the bride of Ronald W. Spira
Nov. 4 in a ceremony con
ducted by Rabbi Marcus Bre
ger at the home of the bride’s
parents, Mr. and Mrs. Irving
Lavine.
Mr. Spira, son of Mr. and
Mi's. Leo W. Spira of Sche
nectady, N.Y., graduated
from Syracuse University in
1959 and taught in Verona,
N.Y. schools before coming
to Tucson as youth activity
aide at the Jewish Commu
nity Center.
The bride graduated from
Tucson High and attended
Lamson Business School. She
is now employed by Eagle
Bakery.
The couple is now at home
at 4388 E. Bellevue following
a honeymoon in Las Vegas
and at Lake Mead.
• • •
In a ceremony conducted
by Rabbi Marcus Breger in
the synagogue of Cong. An
shei Israel on Dec. 23, Mrs.
Anna Schrank became the
bride of Morris Grossman.
Mrs. Grossman has been
active in the Sisterhood of
Cong. Young Israel.
Mr. Grossman is a mem
ber of the Anshei Israel
board and also a board mem
ber of the Jewish Nursing
Home for the Aged.
o
DETROIT (JTA)—Leaders
of all groups in the Detroit
Jewish community paid trib
ute to Isidore Sobeloff, exec
utive vice-president of the
Jewish Welfare Federation
on the occasion of his com
pletion of 25 years of service
in Detroit.
THE ARIZONA POST-
BB Women
Set Annual
Luncheon
B’nai B’rith Women Chap
ter 613 will hold its annual
paid-up membership lunch
eon at noon on Jan. 23 at
the Center.
A short business session
will be held at 1 p.m. followed j
by a candlelight ritual cere->
mony entitled, “Tree of
Light.” It is based on the
symbol of the B’nai B’rith
order, the seven-branch Me
norah. Through the cere
mony all members who have
joined the group since May
31 will be initiated into the
chapter.
Mrs. Morris Podolsky is
luncheon chairman. The
luncheon fee is a $1 donation.
Those who have completed
dues payment will be admit
ted without charge.
Further information on the
luncheon may be received
from Mrs. Alexander Berko
witz, president.
—o
City Os Hope
Holds SIOO
Dinner
The Tucson Chapter of
City of Hope will hold a
SIOO dinner Sunday night
at the Saddle and Sirloin.
Fred Rosen is chairman
for the dinner which be
gins at 6 p.m.
Entertainment for the
dinner features the DeCas
tro Sisters and Dave Bur
ton. Proceeds from the
dinner will go to the City
of Hope Pilot Medical Cen
ter.
o
Record Bested
By Hank Green
Hank Green bowled a new
high single game and high
series for The Arizona Post
Bowling League Wednesday
night.
Going 102 pins over his
average, Hank hit 269 and
finished with a 163-245-269
677 record series.
Other top performances in
cluded a 206 game and 577
series by Sam Sher, 557 by
Bill Rappaport; 207 and 556
by Harry Camen; 551 by
George Holi ck; 537 by
George Fischer; 526 by Paul
Ash; 525 by Irv Fierson and
205 and 544 by Loon Meyer
son.

ENGAGEE—Miss Regina Weiss
IlllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllillllHl
Engagements
iiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiii
Mr. and Mrs. Alex E. Weiss
announce the engagement of
their daughter, Regina, to
Claude Frank, son of Mrs.
S. Frank of Lyon, France.
Miss Weiss graduated from
the University of Arizona
where she was a member of
Phi Kappa Phi and Phi Al
pha Theta. She studied at the
Hebrew University in Jeru
salem for two years and for
a year at the Ecole Nationale
des Langue Orientales Vivan
tes in France. She is now
completing work towards a
masters degree in political
science at the University of
California and is making her
home in New York City.
Mr. Frank is a graduate
of the Ecole Nationale Supe
rieure d’electrotechnique de
Grenoble and holds a license
en-sciences from the Univer
sity of Grenoble. He received
his masters degree in engi
neering from the University
of California where he held
French government and
Fulbright fellowships. He
now is with IBM World
Trade Corp. in New York
City.
• • •
Mr. and Mrs. David Cher
kas of Brookline, Mass., have
announced the engagement
of their daughter, Barbara
Ruth, to Harold A. Malinsky,
son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving
L. Malinsky of Tucson.
The wedding has been set
for Feb. 3 at Temple Sholom
at the Medfoi’d Jewish Com
munity Center in Medford,
Mass.
Miss Cherkas graduated
from Boston U. and is teach
ing at Medford High School
and in the division of con
tinuing education at Bos
ton U.
Mr. Malinsky attended the
University of California and
is an alumnus of the Univer
sity of Arizona. He is em
ployed by the Electronics
Corp. of America in Cam
bridge, Mass., and is a can
didate for a law degree at
the Suffolk University Law
School.

Representing Tucson’s Sab

Calif., were DINA LEVIN,
LESLIE DUNN and CAROL
BLUTH . . .
• • •
NORMAN FISCH recently
was honored by Dumont-
Emerson Co. at a dinner here
as the nation’s top television
salesman. It was the first
time the award has been won
by the same person for three
consecutive years . . .
• • •
DON GOLOS has qualified
for the Arizona Leaders
Round Table for the third
consecutive year, it has been
announced by New York Life
Insurance Co. Last year Mr.
Golos won the coveted Na
tional Quality Award and at
tended the company’s Star
Club Convention. In his var
ied activities Mr. Golos
serves CJA as co-chairman of
the key division, is an advisor
for A1 Jolson AZA and has
been instrumental in form
ing the University of Ari
zona’s Lacrosse Club . . .
• • •
HARRY BACAL was hon
ored by the Metropolitan
Board of the YMCA follow
ing his long service . . .
• • •
MR. AND MRS. MORRIS
REMER have returned to
Tucson after spending the
past two months in Phoenix.
MRS. SAM MEYERSON
wishes to thank all her
friends for their many kind
nesses during her recent hos
pitalization . . .
IRVING YAVELBERG vis
ited with his parents, MR.
AND MRS. SAM YAVEL
BERG, during the holidays.
He is now with Bell Labora

planning for the Telstar shot.
• • •
I. H. HANDMAKER has
been named to the Metropoli

• • •
LT. COL. OSCAR M. LIF

VID PESKINS while appear

They are long-time friends.

TOUGALOO SOUTHERN CHRISTIAN
COLLEGE BEGINS 86th YEAR; START
NEW ENGINEERING PROGRAM
With the inauguration of a new
pre-engineering program, Tougaloo
College opened its 86th academic
year last week, changing its name
to Tougaloo Southern Christian Col
lege.
Approximately 18 students have
enrolled in the new program, which
is offered in conjunction with La
fayette College, Easton, Pa., and is
the only one of its kind available
to Negroes in the deep South.
Heading the pre-engineering pro
gram will be Dr. Ion Carstoiu, who
holds a doctorate in mathematics
from the Sorbonne, Paris. Dr. Car
stoui, who took a degree in aero
nautical engineering at the Ecole
Nationale Superieure De L’Aero
nautique aPris, was assistant pro
fessor of mathematics at Johns Hop
kins University from 1949 to 1952.
He also did research work in the
Department of Aeronautics at the
same university. More recently he
was a research associate in the grad,
uate Institute of Applied Mathema
tics, Indiana University.
Born in Craiova, Romania, Dr.
Carstoiu is a noted European scho
lar.
Dr. Render Tuan, professor of
mathematics and physics, will as
sist Dr. Carstc u in handling the
new three-year, two-year program.
After a preengineering student has
satisfactorily completed the three
year program at Tougaloo Southern
Christian and maintained a good
scholastic avei-ge, he can enroll at
Lafayette, when after two years he
receives both an engineering degree
and a B S. from Tougaloo South
ern College.
The nve additional newcomers
to the faculty include Dr. Victor
M. Bogle, professor of history, Dr.
Charles B. Arzeni, professor of bio
logy, Dr. Carroll W. Palmer, pro
fessor of education, Mr. John T.
Braxton, director of athletics and
head coach, anc5 Miss Mildred Thorn,
pson, assistant professor of physical
education. In addition Mrs* Naomi
Townsend, associate professor of
English, and Dr. Ernst Borinski, pro.
fessor of sociology, have returned
from sabbatical leaves at the uni
versity of Pittsburgh. Mrs. Pearl
Perkins, former assistant registrar,
received her M. A. degree at the
University of Wisconsin and has
been appointed to the department
of education. *
Dr. Bogle, who took his M. A.
and Ph. D. degrees at Boston Uni
versity, has published six articles on
the socio-economic history of New
Albany, Indiana, in the Indiana
Magazine of History. A graduate of
Eastern Illinois State College, Dr.
Arzeni took his M. S. and Ph. D.
degrees at the University of Michi
gan. His thesis was recently pub
lished in its entirety in the “Amer
ican Midland Naturalist". He has
published articles in the "Bryolog
ist” and his laboratory manual is
now in use at the University of
Michigan. Before coming to Toug
aloo Southern Christian College.
Dr. Arzeni spent two years in Iiberia
as research botainist for the Fire
stone Plantations Co., and had taught
at Albion Colleg in Michigan.
Formerly an assistant professor
of physical education at Bethune -
Cookman College, Daytona Beach,
Fla., Mr. Braxton has also served
as athletic director and head coach
at Tillotson College, Austin Texas,
where he turned out two champion
ship teams and successful football
and basketball teams. Braxton
coached football teams won two
state championships at the Indus
troal High School, Fairfield, Ala.
He took his M. A. degree in physi
cal education at New York Univer
sity. Dr. Palmer took his Ph. D.
at Columbia University and also
holds a dgeree in education from
the University of. Alabama. Miss
Thompson did her undergraduate
work at North Carolina College,
Durham, and is a candidate for an
M. S. in physical education there.
Mrs. Townsend, who becomes the
new head of the English Depart
ment is completing work for the
Ph. D. degree at the University of
Pittsburgh. Dr. Borinski, who recent
ly took his Ph. D. degree at the
same institution, has written an
article on “The Sociological and
Legal Interpretation* of the Sup
reme Court decision of March 17,
1954”, which will appear in the
“Pittsburgh Law Review”. He plans
to resume the Social Science For
ums, which have ganied state-wide
recognition in dealing with current
issues of regional and national im
portance.
Assisting Coach Braxton with the
football squad will be Mr. Wilbert
Qwens, who is also an instructor of
physical education at the Tougaloo
Preparatory School. A recent grad
uate of Bethune _ Cookman. Mr
Owens was an All-conference right
end and editor of student publi
cations.
The Incoming freshman class,
which numbers more than 100 stu
dents, was recently put through a
battery of tests designed to mea
sure different apititudes. The class,
one of the most heterogeneous in
the institution’s history, includes
MRA A Global
Force Says
Congressman
Mackinac Island, Mich., — “This
is the most important meeting be
ing held in America this year,” said
Congressman Charles B. Deane of
Nortn Carfolina at the Moral Re
Armament Assembly here today.
“That’s why 1 left a busy election
campaign to come here.”
residents of Alabama, Tennessee,
Virginia, Connecticut, and New
York. Most of the Freshmen come
from Mississippi and more live in
Jackson than in any other city. The
newcomers will don red and blue
Freshman caps early this week as
they settle down to regular cam
pus routine.
$60,000 has been spent during the
summer months on renovating class
room buildings and beautifying the
campus.
Deane continued, “Unless we in
America solve ou* ideological pro
blems we will be sunk. We have
thought we could solve the problem
of Communism by investigation and
by outlawing the party. But unless
we find a superior ideology based
on absolute moial standards and lis
tening to God for guidance, we are
not going t owin. Moral Re-Arma
ment is a global force challenging
the living and thinking of each in
dividual in every country.”
In his primary campaign this year
Congressman Deane met campaign
expenses out of his own pocket,
refusing all donations. He reported
that he had won by over 20,000
votes a larger majority than in any
of his previous campaigns.
John McGovern, for 24 years mem.
ber of the British Parliament from
Glasgow, told the Assembly, “If
the governments of the free world
spent five per cent of their budgets
n Moral Re-Armament, it would do
more to bring freedom and peace
than anything else they could do.
-V-o
There are bett * ways of get
ting up In the world than hitting *
the ceiling.
-o
Persons hardest to convince they
are of retirement age are children
at bedtime.

NQTP/~ QP ART AND ART IAT f
NE of the most notable exhibitions held
M 1 In New York during the past season
u m was a memorial exhibition of the
I M works of Arthur B. Davies at the
Metropolitan Museum from February
17 to March 30. It is gratifying to be able to
announce that this exhibition is coining to
Washington and will be shown here during the
month of May in the Corcoran Gallery of Art.
Washingtonians have made acquaintance
with Arthur B. Davies through paintings ex
hibited from time to time in the Corcoran Gal
lery's biennial exhibitions and through im
portant examples included in the Phillips
Memorial Gallery’s permanent collection. But
at no time has so comprehensive a showing of
his works been seen in this city; in fact, such
a comprehensive collection was not assembled
during the artist’s lifetime. For the privilege
shortly to be enjoyed by Washingtonians we
are indebted not only to the Corcoran Gallery
of Art, but to Mrs. Arthur B. Davies, the artist’s
widow, who herself has made the arrangements,
in conference and co-operation with Mr. Min
nigerode, director of the Corcoran Gallery. The
collection will consist of paintings in oil and
water color, etchings and lithographs, and pos
sibly certain works in applied art, such as de
signs for tapestries and rugs and the woven
fabrics themselves.
Arthur B. Davies is perhaps the only artist
ardently admired by both traditionalists and
modernists, though he belonged to neither
school. He was a poet and dreamer, always in
search of beauty, absolutely individualistic in
his expression.
A most interesting and excellent book on
Davies was issued a few years ago by the Phil
lips Memorial Gallery, containing appreciative
essays by Duncan Phillips, Royal Cortissoz,
Frank Jewett Mather, jr.; Edward W. Root and
others —a magnificent tribute to the artist's
genius.
jV/fUCH interest attaches to the excellent por
trait of the late Chief Justice Taft by
Ernest L. Ipsen, which was placed on view
in the Corcoran Gallery recently and may still
be seen there.
This portrait was painted from sittings last
Autumn and was shown first in New York,
prior to Justice Taft’s death, at the Century
Club. It was painted as a commission from
one of Chief Justice Taft’s old neighbors and
ardent admirers in New Haven, who prefers to
remain nameless, and is purposed as a gift
and permanent memorial for the United States
Supreme Court.
It is undoubtedly one of the most satisfactory
portraits of the former President and Chief
justice that has been painted, and the artist
seems to have obtained a most characteristic
expression. Mr. Taft is represented in his legal
robes, standing beside a column, presumably
» in the Supreme Court room, with a document
in his left hand, his eyeglasses in his right
hand. The impression produced is that he has
paused on the instant, removed his glasses and
is about to speak. It is a simple, stralghtfor
• ward piece of painting, the artist suppressing
his own personality in it that the personality
of his distinguished sitter may be dominant.
But those who know cannot fail to recognize
in this work the hand of the master painter,
the intelligence of the discerning eye.
Mr. Ipsen is undoubtedly one of our leading
American portrait painters today. He has had
many distinguished sitters. Among his best
known works are his portraits of Otis Bkinner
as Mister Antonio, Dr. John Bates Clark for
the Carnegie Endowment for International
Peace, Elihu Root for the Century Association,
New York; Edwin Howland Blashfield for the
National Academy of Design, Dr. Henry Van
Dyke for the Princeton Club of New York and
George A. Plimpton for Amherst College.
Mr. Ipsen was represented In the exhibition
shown in Budapest last Winter, under the
auspices of the American Federation of Arts,
by an engaging portrait of Capt. Robert A.
Bartlett, navigator and explorer. He paints
women as well as men, interpreting feminine
grace with the utmost charm.
Bom in Malden, Mass., in 1869, he studied
at the Boston Museum School and at the Royal
Academy at Copenhagen. In 1924 he was made
■

hour (J clock Ladies, a painting by Arthur B. Davies. 'I his painting is contained in the exhibition which will be
placed in the Corcoran Gallery in May.
THE SUNDAY STAR, WASHINGTON, D. C., APRIL 27, I<>3o.
jr LEILA MbCHLIN
The Davies Exhibition to Be Placed in the
Corcoran Gallery of Art in May—Excellent
Portrait of the Late Chief Justice Taft.
liH ■
Hi * i
Portrait of the late Chief Justice William Howard Taft, paintetl by Ernest
L. Ipsen. The work is now on view at the Corcoran Gallery.
a National Academician. He is a life member
of the National Arts Club, a member of the
Salmagundi Club, the Century Association, the
American Federation of Arts and other pro
fessional organizations. He has been awarded
the Proctor prize and the Isaac N. Maynard
prize by the N. A. D., and is represented In
the permanent collections of the Chicago Art
Institute, the Art Institute of Youngstown and
other public institutions. His studio is at the
National Arts Club, New York.
TPHE Corcoran Gallery of Art has recently re
hung a number of its galleries and the
walls of the upper atrium. The occasion for
this was the replacement of wall covering. The
new arrangement is attractive and doubtless
advantageous, but those familiar with the old
hanging will be somewhat at a loss, at first, to
locate old favorites.
The semi-circular gallery, wherein for a num
ber of years transient exhibitions were shown,
is now given over exclusively to the display of
works by early American painters and those
of the so-called Hudson River School. Adjacent
to this is a gallery now devoted entirely to
portraits by early American painters, beauti
fully spaced and grouped. Prom here on the
collection has been hung chronologically and
in accordance with the new mode of ample
spacing.
It is a long step from the days of the old
gallery on the corner of Pennsylvania avenue
and Seventeenth street, where the principal
works in the permanent collection were assem
bled in one huge room and hung not only frame
to frame but in two or three rows, and the
present day, when almost as much attention is
paid to placement as to acquisition. The art
of display has indeed, in this later era, made
great advance. Perhaps most notable in the
new arrangement of paintings at the Corcoran
Gallery is the placement in the atrium of paint
ings produced between 1870 and 1900. But
these for the most part are subject pictures, or
pictures painted with realistic intent, and there
fore bear close inspection, while at the same
time being effective at a distance. For this
reason they lend themselves to exhibition in
the atrium better than the more modern works.
Another change that visitors may note is the
removal of the seated statue of Napoleon from
the center ol the upper atrium to the center
of the northwest sculpture room on the first
floor, and its replacement by a work in bropze
by a cotemporary American artist. This Stas
done not from lack of appreciation of the
artistic merit of the Napoleon, but in order to
follow definite classification, this statue of
Napoleon being the work of Vincenzo Vela, an
Italian sculptor bom in 1822, who studied in
Switzerland.
It is perhaps interesting to know that this
statue once belonged to John Taylor Johnston
of New York, the first president of the Metro
politan Museum of Art and one of the first
Americans to assemble a notable private collec
tion. It was purchased for the Corcoran Gal
lery at the John Taylor Johnston sale, as was
also, by the way, the beautiful painting of
Niagara Falls by F. E. Church.
AT the Arts Club there opened last Sunday,
to continue until May 3, exhibitions of
paintings by Mary.G. Riley of this city, Gladys
Brannigan, formerly of Washington, and Ale
thea Platt of New York. Miss Riley’s paintings
occupy the lounge and dining room. Mrs.
Brannigan and Alethea Platt share the as
sembly room.
Miss Riley’s exhibits, all works in oil, are
13 in number—landscapes and still life, the
former predominating. They are all frank,
straightforward paintings, good in color, virile
and sincere, conveying to the observer an im
pression of not only competence, but insight
on the part of the painter. Among the most
interesting are Spanish and Portuguese themes
—pictures, strangely enough, of a country not
unlike that which the Spaniards discovered find
claimed, Mexico and our own Southwest—ex
tremely picturesque, essentially paintable.
But Miss Riley has painted in this country
also, and she shows no less characteristic in
terpretations of the Vermont hills, a “New
England Village”; “Old Bruton Church at Wil
liamsburg, Va.” and “Dorset Hollow.” A de
lightfully varied, but uniformily good showing.
Mrs. Brannigan and Miss Platt paint in such
entirely different manner that their works
agreeably complement one another. Mrs. Bran
nigan uses a full brush, strong color and crisp
accent. Miss Platt paints with considerable
reserve and gives her work a rather lyrical qual
ity. A number of her exhibits are subject pic
tures, in which figures are nicely placed. Her
still life studies are exceptionally engaging.
Mrs. Brannigan is at her best in landscape,
and among her most interesting contributions
to this showing is “Lane in Spring,” though
each of her contributions suggests keen insight
and delight in nature.
JN addition to the exhibitions by these three
woman artists, announced previously in
these columns and also In the Arts Club Bul
letin, a special exhibition has been arranged
in the assembly room, on the second floor of
the club, of studies of fish by a French artist,
M. Elie Cheverlange, who is at present resi
dent in Washington, while engaged in making
illustrations In color and black and white for
one of the scientific publications to be issued
by the Smithsonian Institution.
He was bom in Limoges, France, in 1876, the
son of a painter on porcelain. After the usual
schooling he studied at the Ecole Nationale des
Arts Decoratifs of Limoges, and himself became
a porcelain painter. In 1895 he went to Paris
and took up poster design and illustration.
Later he went to England, where he obtained
employment in a lithographic house. In 1900
he came to America and worked for several
commercial lithographers. Eventually he found
himself in San Francisco, and from there
drifted to Japan and China. In Shanghai he
worked for a French newspaper as a cartoonist.
In Indo-China he served as draftsman for a
surveyng party in the Yunnan Province. There
he contracted jungle fever, to rid himself of
which he returned byway of India, Java and
Australasia to Europe. Since that time he has
served in the war, receiving a Croix de Guerre
with three citations and various other awards.
Since the war he has lived in the South Seas,
mostly In Tahiti, studying artistically and
scientifically, ocean life.
His paintings have apparently met with the
approval of both scientists and artists, and the
descriptive texts which he has supplied for the
present exhibits, as well as a brief essay in
praise of the subject, are extremely illuminating.
This is a unique exhibit.
THE re B iona l meeting held by the American
Federation of Arts in Santa Fe, N. Mex.,
April 16, 17 and 18 proved exceptionally inter
esting. There was a wide attendance from
States as far west as California, as far north

FEDERAL EMPLOYE
WINS PARIS AWARD
Theobold Holsopple to Study
Year Abroad in Recognition
of Work in Design.
Theobold Holsopple of 638 Keefer
place has been awarded the third-place
medal and a cash prize of $150 and
the privilege of entering the "first
class" of the Ecole Nationale des Beaux
Arts, in Paris, for a year's study, in the
competition for the 1932 Paris prize, It
was announced here yesterday.
Mr. Holsopple. one of the four final
ists In the prize competition, captured
third-place honors with his solution of
the problem assigned to the finalists,
the designing of a national opera house
for Washington.
Holsopple was graduated from Cath
olic University in 1929. He has been
working recently in the field depart
ment of the constructing quartermaster
of the War Department. '
Becoming one of the four finalists
to compete for the Paris prize in archi- ,
tecture meant that he was one of the ,
25 winners among the 580 student who
entered the first preliminary exercise
for the competition, held early in Jan- ,
uary; that he was one of the eight
winners of the second round of com
petition held a month lat«r; and that ι
he was one of the four winners chosen '
to enter the finals as a result of the
final preliminary sketch on April 8.
Richard H. Granelli of New York was
winner of the prize, with Max Abram
ovitz of New York as alternate and
second-place winner.
Joseph H. Freelander was chairman
of the group of architects serving on
the 1urv of awards.
RISE IN PROSPERITY
SEEN BY VIRGINIAN
J)r. Freeman of Richmond Tells
Bankers Bottom of Depression
Is Beached.
By the Associated Press.
NEWPORT NEWS, Va.. June 25.—Dr.
Douglas S. Freeman of Richmond,
fpeaking before the Virginia Bankers'
Association at Old Point Comfort tcday,
said he believed the bottom of the de
pression had been reached in the United
States, but he did not consider the In
ternational situation so favorable.
He predicted a gradual rise in pros
perity. but discredited any belief that
an inflation such as that of 1928 would
recur.
Arthur J. Linn, controller of the Fed
eral American National Bank & Trust
Co., Washington, gave an impromptu
talk on "Seme Thoughts on the New
Bank Tax."
MATTIE LAIRD WINNER
AT AVIATION MEETING
Plane Builder Flies First Race in
Ten Tears to Carry Away
First Honors.
By the Associated Press.
NIAGARA FALLS. Ν. Y„ June 25 —
Flying his first race in 10 years, Mattie
Laird. Chicago plane builder who de
signed and constructed the ship which
won the Thompson Trophy at Cleveland
in 1930, took top honors at today's air
races by winning the 20-mile free
for-all.
Laird, piloting a special ship of his
own design, won handily over Art Davis
of Lansing. Mich., who placed second,
and Jack Morris of Pittsburgh, third
place winner.
Jerry Nettleton of Toledo was the ,
heaviest money winner today, winning
the dead-stick landing contest, placing
second in the baloon-bursting contest
and fourth 1 na race for small-motored
planes. Close behind him was Harold
Neumann of Moline, 111., with two sec
onds and a third.
A sportsman's handicap race, limited
to amateurs, was won by John Wright
cf Utica ; Paul Blum of Davenport,
Iowa, placed second, and Bill Warrick
of Cleveland, third.
LOAN FIRM HEAD JAILED
Colorado Spring's Man Will Fight
Extradition on False Heturns.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo.. June
25 (TP).—E. C. Sharer, president of the
Dollar Building & Loan Association,
now in the hands of a receiver, was ar
rested in Los Angeles today on a war
rant charging him with making false re
turns. Sharer announced he would
fight extradition. The warrant charges
he exaggerated assets of the association
by 5153,259.
W. C. Davis, missing president of the
defunct City Savings Building & Loan
Association, had an interest in the Dol
lar Building & Loan Co. Authorities
and Receiver Charles T. Fertig have
been unable to locate $1,270,000 Gov
ernment bonds believed to have been
in Davis' possession.
GARDEN FETE WEDNESDAY
Annual Affair of Disciples Home
for Aged.
The annual garden fete of the
Disciples Heme for the Aged will be
held Wednesday evening at 2800 Thir
teenth street. In connection with the
Bicentennial celebration, hostesses and
others will wear Colonial costumes.
Mrs. G. T. Warren, chairman, is being
assisted by Mrs. Emma Roy, Mrs. Rose
Runkles. Mrs. Raymond Snarr, Mrs.
Clarence Brant. Mrs. O. L. Beardsley,
Mrs. H. Gravett. Mrs. Sara McMillan,
Mrs. O. G. Whitlow and Mr. and Mrs.
G. P. Mergell.
As an additional attraction there will .
be an indoor play and music at 8:15
and 9:15 o'clock.
Wins Scholarship
CATHOLIC UNIVERSITY GRAD
UATE EARNS K. OF C. AWARD.
JOSEPH T. DE BETTEXCOl'RT,
3on of Mr. end Mrs. Joseph S. De Bet
;enccart, 3905 Thirteenth street north
;ast. was the only Washington boy
imong 10 Catholic University graduates
ecently awarded the Knights of Colum
)us scholarship. Joseph, who is 19, was
the youngest member of this year's
rraduating class. The scholarship en
titles him to take a post-graduate
:ourse in electrical engineering through
.932 and 1933. with all expenses paid.
iis father is an examiner.
—Brocks Photo.
FITS DESCRIPTION (
OF SLAYING VICTIM Γ
Body Taken From Mississippi River
in Arkansas Linked With St
Louis Crime.
By the Associated Press.
GREENVILLE, Miss., June 25—The !
body of a man believed to fit the j
description of Clyde Bailey, 40, whom
Orville James Turley, under arrest at [
Detroit. Mich., confessed slaying, was !
found in the Mississippi Hiver at Lume,
Ark., late yesterday. The body was
turned over to county authorities at
Lake Village. Ark.
Chief of Police William Taggart of
Greenville, notified Detroit police today.
Lune. Ark., Is 20 miles north of here.
Officers said the man had been shot ι
over the left eye.
Thin hair of the head and other |
features tallied with the description of s
Bailey, Chief Taggart said.
Turley. escaped Colorado convict, told j
Detroit authorities he killed Bailey on |
an Illinois highway and threw the body j
into the Mississippi River at St. Louis.
He said thev had quarreled over the|
] division of $14.000 obtained in a money ι
j order fraud by tapping telegraph wires j
in Michigan.

ber. Special exhibition of Water Colors

An exhibition of Bicentennial Portraits
of Washington and other historic per

, BEARS. ROEBUCK A CO . 1106 Con
necticut avenue. Special exhibition of

Etchings by Philip Gddens of New

Crayon paintings by Joseph Btrren.

VENABLE S. 1309 H street. Pastels by

BY FLORENCE S. BERRYMAN.
A 186 LEILA MECHLIN, who in Bd
A dition to being art writer of The
j \ Star, is secretary of the Ameri
/ \ can Federation of Arts and di
' m rector of its department of
1 advisory service, went to Omaha,
ffebr.. March 28 to attend the federation’s fifth
Western conference st the Joslyn Memorial
March 31 through April 2. She presented a
peport at the opening se-sion and presided at
a number of the other sessions. From Omaha
Mies Mechlin went to Los Angeles to make
arrangement* for the competition of work* by
■•tug artists and the exhibition of art in rela
tion to sport, to be held in connection with
Ike tenth Olympiad next July 30 to August 14.
She is director of the American art section.
Which will include architecture, painting,
graphic arts, sculpture and medals. The exhi
bition will occupy 19 galleries in the Los An
geles Museum of History, Science and Art.
AOBOUP of water color* by Charles Hop
kinson was placed on exhibition in the
glass cases on the second floor st the Corcoran
Oellery last Monday.
Although he has painted water colors for
taany years, as a complement to his portrait
■aark. Mr. Hopkinson is still perhaps best known
for the latter. Three outstanding examples
Ire in the National Gallery of Art collection
a< war portraits—Premier Bratisno, Premier
Paslurh and Prince Snonji. AU are painted
- With great vitality, in the traditional manner.
The water colors reveal a very different facet
af Mr Hopkins mi s ierrat>le talent. With free
flow* in choice of subject matter comes also a
greater freedom in handling. Done in a very
fluid wash, the water colors have a spontaneity
and verve that suggest the fresh salty air of
the sea coast, whfh most of them represent.
These are Summer seas, sapphire blue under
a brilliant sun. which warms the b^re. rocky
covas where bathers stretch themselves in
leisure hours Again, it is evening, and the
setting sun makes a golden blaze in the sky,
or. in quieter mood, leaves a silver path across
the water.
The broad handling of these water colors
gives them tremendous carrying quality. They
Should be Viewed 20 or 30 feet away; in fact,
- they are best seen from either end of the cor
ridor around the atrium. Here the unpainted
portions of paper become reflections on the
water, clouds or whatever the artist intended
them to be. At this distance these water colors
aeem not represent aiions, but the very raaenrr
Of the places depicted
This exhibition will remain through April 34.
JVater Colors on Exhibition at the Corcoran
Gallery of Art—Special Shozvings at the
Phillips Gallery—Other Local Notes.
"The Dmys of '40" mm Mr king by Eugene Higtms. In exhibition mt the
Smithsonimn.
AT the Phillips Memorial Gallery two special
exhibitions are on view, a memorial group
Wt works by Robert, spencer, throughout April
mid May. and the first ‘'one-man*' show of a
local artist, Helen Sewell Johnson, for the
The Sponcci exhibition includes several of
the large paintings from the permanent col
lection at the Phillips Gallery. “The Auction"
“The evangelist." "Ship Chandlers' Row"
"Mountebanks and Thieves.” and six which
have been lent for this exhibition. Five at
them are mnall paintings, at single figures or
groups. “The Laundress.'' 'Ragpickers." eC
the sixth b similar in type to Mr. Phillips
examples, it represents “Three Houses.” in
the grayed colors characteristic at the artist.
Robe** Spencer was always Intensely interested
In painting buildings, and be gave these shabby
oM frame houses on the water front more per
sonality than he painted in the people Inhabit
tng them
• lighthouse stands guard. Ms harsh notan m
tensi lying the feeling at constant danger.
Again, there M “Sardine Factory,” In which all
the dreary dinginess of such a place is com
pressed in this mustard-colored structure on
its sagging wharf, with aa overcast sky and a
lone worker at leisure. A whimsical painting.
“Oat and Jacks,” is done presumably from a
chikl’a point at view—these toys tn red. blue
and yellow, with grayed secondary ootan in the
background, suggest, the brightness at play,
■dually light-hearted in feeling are “Plaster
Dog” and “New England Interior.” ht which
the dog again appears, conjuring up memo
ries of serene days in old houses at rural New
England, with their naive furnishings.
N exhibition of contemporary American oil
paintings, water colon, etchings and other
graphic aria, and loan exhibitions of decorative
arte were opened at the galleries at Sears. Roe
buck * Co hut Tuesday evening with a pri
vate view. Among those present were the guest
at honor, Mrs. Lowell Fletcher Hobart, presi
dent general of the Daughters of the American
Revolution; three of the exhibiting artists,
Philip Hams Giddens, etcher; William J.
Potter and Sandor Vago, painters, as well as
the Most Rev. Joseph Schrembs. Bishop of
Cleveland, whose portrait by Mr. Vago is on
view in the main gallery.
In this gallery are 21 other oil paintings by
Mr. Vago, a number of paintings by Mr. Potter
and examples of Oriental art from the collec
tion of Albert J. Osgood of this city The
latter Include ancient Chinese and Thibetan
paintings, bronae and pewterware. palace em
broideries from China and Burma, fabrics and
brocades presented by the late Empress Dowager
to the wife of a former consul at Nanking, and
porcelains of the Yung Cbing and Tao Kuang
periods.
Sandor Vago's work comprises portraits, fig
ure paintings, flowers and still life, done with
a very fluid brush and considerable facility.
Viewing Mias Johnson's painting in Gallery
E, it Is difficult to realise that die studied
under such painters as Richard Merman at
the Corcoran School of Art. Iran Othiaky at
the National Academy of Design Schools and
Charies Hawthorne, for her work is markedly
in the modern idiom, both in technique and
mood She uses the low-keyed earth odors
characteristic of many modernists and there
is strong emotional feeling in some at her
paintings. Adding personal interest to the
exhibition Is a self-portrait as well as two other
portraits of women, individual characterisations,
with solidly painted form arid telling uae of
shadows, and without distortion. Mias Johnson
frequently relieves her dark-toned palette with
lighter colors, as in the beautiful Persian blue
dress of “Marina." and the lemon yellow tea
pot and pale blue textile in her “Still Life.”
She habitually spends her Summers in Prov
tneetown or other seaports, as may be seen hi
some of her paintings in the current exhibition.
"The Wolves." for instance, are rocks jutting
above the surface of an angry sea, over which
“Sardine Factory,'’ a painting by Seuell Johnson. Inc luded in exhibition at
the Phillips Gallery. * * *
to judge from the vivacious appearance of his
subjects Although a native of Hungary, where
he was born in 1887, Mr Vago has made his
home in Cleveland for about 10 years. He
has been the recipient of two awards from
the Cleveland Museum of Art. which lias one
of his flower paintings in its permanent col
lection. Other examples of his work are in
the public library, several clubs and a number
of private collections in Cleveland. Mr. Vago
is also represented In the National Salon,
Budapest, of which he a as a founder member.
He studied at the Royal Academies of Budapest
and Munich.
Although his portraits are v.’ry colorful and
effective, particularly those of the Bishop of
Cleveland, and of two Hungarian aristocrats.
all sumptuously dad, Mr. Vago's figure paint
ings. such as “Jim.'’ an excellent characteriza
tion; “Silver Hat," "Old Lady" and others,
have greater interest and variety in types and
poses.
Occupying an entire room are the etchings,
water colors and crayon drawings by Philip
Harris Guldens, his second exhibition in Wash
ington. He first exhibited at Gordon Dun
thome's in January. 1928. and a number of the
subjects then shomn are included in the present
display. Among them Is the last print in his
edition of "The Mosque of Santa Sophia. Con
stantinople." a view of the Interior, of which
the varied details are exquisitely rendered. This
print was the turning point in the artist's
career. He was born in Cuthbert. Georgia, in
1887. attended the Georgia School of Tech
nology and there won the architectural scholar
ship given by the American Field Service to
French universities. For three years he studied
in Paris at l'Ecole Nationale des Beaux Arts,
and traveled extensively, managing to visit 15
European countries during this period Al
though he was studying architecture, etching
had long been a hobby with Mr. Giddens, and
one which absorbed all his spare time. His
etching of Santa Sophia; submitted to the
Grand Salon in Paris, in 1923. received honor
able mention from the Societe des Artistes
Prancais, an unexpected success which en
couraged him to abandon architecture alto
gether. in order to devote himself entirely to
the work in which he had the greatest interest.
His etchings have been acquired for the moot
important permanent collections of print* in
Great Britain and Prance a* well a* the United
States. Other proofs from these same plates
are in the exhibition at the Sears. Roebuck
galleries. The British Museum has the "Santa
Sophia." “Entrance to La Ville Close. Con
carneau." "St. Jean Pied de Port” and "The
Chicago Tribune Tower," the last being also
in the Victoria and Albert Museum. London,
which has alao "The Spire of Notre Dame,
Paris.” The Library of Congress ha* recently
acquired the "Loggia dei Lanzi, Florence." a
superb piece of work. Mr. Giddens choae a
▼tew looking toward the Palasao Vecchio and
showing two of the monuments, the "Menehms"
and the "Rape of Polyxena,” and has simul
taneously indicated scale and added a touch of
humor in the weary tourists resting on the
base of the latter monument. In addition to
these collections, the Bibiiotheque Nationale.
Paris, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and
New York Public Library, the Art Institute of
Chicago, St. Louis. Kansas City and Brooklyn
Museums aU have examples of Mr. Guldens'
work.
Although the majority of these etchings are
the fruit of the artist’s sojourns abroad, a
number of them depict American buildings. Of
particular interest to us is the "White House,
south facade,” which Mr. Giddens has both
etched and painted in water colors, a serene
and beautiful view in green, blue and white,
with well placed shadows indicating bright
sunshine. -The Capitol” and "Christ Church.
Alexandria. Va.," are also among the subjects
of water color drawings, as meticulously ren
dered as the etchings, and painted with a
smoothly applied wash. A number of these
etchings are being simultaneously exhibited in
the Paris Salon this month.
In addition to the foregoing, there are also
at the Sears, Roebuck galleries a superb group
of lithographs by Joseph Pennell from the pri
vate collection of Lesaing Rosen wild of Phila
delphia. crayon paintings by Joseph Boren,
portraits, landscapes and drawings by Wil
liam J. Potter, oils and water colors by L. C.
Mitchell, water color drawings by Harold Gaae

BARE BACKS NOTED
AS SEASIBE MODE
Men Doff Shirts, While Wom
en Give Sun Scope in
Seeking Comfort.
By the Associated Prees.
CHICAGO. June 27 —With the
mercury trying for altitude records in
many sections, the call of the sea. like,,
river and swimming pool precipitates — ;
At least in the feminin- mind-the
problem of what is smart in beach
As for the men, the beach parade j
shows many are solving the bathing j
suit style very simply—a pair of shorts, i
the shirt of which is hung on the
hickory limb. 1
After elbowing one's way through
suddenly crowded bathing suit sections'
of loading stores, the last word in splash \
outfits was lined up—and the general
impression was that the accent is on
accessories.
Bare Backs in Vogue.
The Idea of giving the violet rays
plenty of surface on which to work
holds as strong as personal taste —and
the beach censors—will permit. Some
of the newest sun-tan suits have noth
ing between the feminine back and
sunshine but a few dutiful straps, and
one new model has a zipper down the
back.
Stylists confided that hand-knit
bathing suits or those that appear so
are the last word- On"-piece suits that
look as though they were two-Diece are
smart. White suits with gay aci -ssories
are In the forefront. Combinations of '
■ brown and white, yellow and brown,
have fashion's sanction as do striped
shirts.
Ensembles Prevalent.
Matching ensembles are the thing—
cap, shoes and belt in white or colored
pebbled rubber: robe, bag. cap or shoes;
bathing suit, jacket and trousers.
Bright and new are gaily colored
liner, overalls worn over striped polo
shirts for beach parading or lolling in
the sun. Cartwheel straw hats, wooden
• clogs, and pajama sandals are worn
with beach pajamas, which are espe
cially popular in linen or jersey.
Three-piece knit yachting pajamas
with gob trousers have recently been 1
launched as an innovation for feminine
sailors.
DEAN MURPHY BACK
FROM PARIS REUNION
Catholic IT. Architectural Head
Meets Premier and Edge on
Beaux-Arts Trip.
Dr. Frederick V. Murphy, dean of the
school of architecture at Catholic Uni- ;
versity, returned last week from Paris, .
' where he attended a reunion of former
' students of the Ecole Nationale des
Beaux-Arts, and assisted in the pres
entation to the school of a monument- I
&1 flagpole, the gift of American archi
tects.
An exhibit of student art, brought
from America to France, was inaugu
rated by the American architects there.
Four students of the Catholic Univer
sity School of Architecture were rep- !
resented in the exhibit. They are J. E
McDonald. T. H. Locraft, R. G. Mar- 1
. quard and R. C. Davis. Special inter- j
est was aroused by Mr. Locrafts “City l
Hall,” the winner of the Paris prize in.
1 *1929.
. The party of which Dr. Murphy was
a member was received by Premier
Pierre Laval and w r as entertained by
Ambassador and Mrs. Edge at the
American Embassy and at th- Colonial
exhibition being held this Summer in
Paris-
STONE BEING PLACED
TO CONNECT PARKWAYS
Hew Road Between Approaches
and X Street Ejected to Be Open
in Few Months.
Officials of the Office of Public Build
ings and Public Parks expect to have
the roadway between the Rock Creek
and Potpmac Parkway approach and K
street, jn. shape for public use w’ithin
a few months.
The base stone is being placed in
position, and surfacing of this new
. highway will commence shortly. Sewers,
• water, curbing and some landscaping
are already in and the work is moving
forward rapidly.
Later, the section from K street to
Pennsylvania avenue will be completed,
but soon It will be possible to motor
from K street to Constitution avenue.
The Rock Creek and Potomac Park
way approach, which leads on to the
Lincoln Memorial plaza and the Arling
ton Memorial Bridge, has not as yet
boen surfaced.
Canada has'shipped more than 100,-
000 pounds of butter to England this
year, It being a new .Industrial depart
ure for the Dominion.

JOSEPHINE DUNN, FILM AC
TRESS, GETS $75 MONTHLY.
jjP] Ilk
LOS ANGELES. June 27 <£»>.—Jo
sephine Dunn, blonde screen actress,
was awarded temporary alimony of $75
a month by the Superior Court, pend
ing trial of the divorce suit filed by
Clyde E. Greathouse, son of an oil
operator.
Science
Apparently IS’etv Mental
Disease Is Reported.
AN apparenily new mental disease is
reported from Russia by Prof. P. B.
Gannuskin of the F.rst Moscow
State University.
j He describes it as “psychic invalid
j ism.” It attacks chiefly young men
: who have been subjected to a long pe
riod of overwork and overrcsponMbility.
i There is a marked decline of intelli
gence. explosive temper outbursts,
Keriods of depression and hysteria with
eadaches, fatigue and fainting spells,
j This condition develops over three or
i four years.
i It is quite different from the well
known dementia precox. Prof. Gannu
skin says, in that it runs a definite
course, at the end of which the regres
sion stops. Its symptoms are some
what like those of severe neurasthenia,
but no amount of rest appears to do
any good.
The victim never is able to do high
! grade mental work again, but adjusts
I very well to mechanical tasks. He
simply falls to a lower level and stays
there without continuing toward in
sanity. It will be found, the Russian
professor insists, that the overstrain
has caused some definite physical dam
age to the cortex of the brain before
1 which physicians are helpless
T. R. H.
MAN HELD IN CHICAGO
SUSPECTED OF ROBBERY
Harvey Lee. 28, of the 1700 block of
, Fourteenth street i» being hold by Chi
! cago police for local authorities in con
; nectlon with a r*cen, robbery and the
theft of an automobile here Sunday.
I Detective Sergt. H. K. Wilson left
for Chicago last night to bring back
Lee for questioning in connection with
a robbery at the Standard Automotive
Supply Co., 1809 Fourteenth street,
where Lee was employed, in which a
duplicate-key thief stole SBO in cash
and S2O worth of tools.
At the time of his arrest in Chicago
Lee was driving an automobile which
police say he hired from a rental agency
here on Sunday and failed to return.

Born in Craiova, Romania, Dr.
Carstoiu is a noted European
scholar. He took his B.S. in En
gineering at the University of
Bucharest. Before the Second
World War he was a civilian en
gineer with the Romanian Air
Force and Assistant professor at
the Institute of Technology, Buch
arest. During the war he was a
civilian engineer with the Roman
ian Air Force in Russia. In No
vember, 1942, he was at Stalingrad
before the Russians mounted the
massive counter-offensive that en
veloped the Axis armies. In
France following the war he was
an assistant in the Faculty of
Sciences at the Sorbonne and also
a research attache at the National
Center of Scientific Research.
Dr. Carstoiu has published 34
papers, many of which appeared
in the “Comptes Rendue s” of the
French Academy of Sciences, Paris.
A memoire on "Vorticity and De
formation in Fluid Mechanics” will
appear shortly in the "Journal of
Rational Mechanics and Analysis
published at Indiana University. He
has done considerable research in
rational mechanics, fluid mechan
ics, and operational calculum.
Dr. Render Tuan, professor of
mathematics and physics, will as
sist Dr. Carstoiu in handling the
new three-year, two-year program.
After a pre-engineering student
has satisfactorily completed the
three year program at Tougaloo
Southern Christian and maintained
a good scholastic average, he can
enroll at Lafayette, where after
two years he receives both an en
gineering degree and a B. S. from
Tougaloo Southern Christian Col
lege.
The five additional newcomers to
the faculty include Dr. Victor M.
Bogle, professor of history, Dr.
Charles B. Arzeni, prjfessor of
Biology, Dr. Carroll W. Palmer,
professor of education, Mr. John
T. Braxton, director of athletics
and head coach, and Miss Mildred

imum of 30 months, under the most

ment. But the new call-up has not
been greeted with enthusiasm by
the hard-pressed European com
munity, many of whom are feeling
the economic pinch of this con
tinuing war against rebellion.
For many of the younger mar
ried businessmen in their late 20s
and early 30s, a call-up notice
spells something close to financial
disaster. Few have the capital to
be able to employ managers, and
those who are running farms sin
gle handed say they will be ruined
unless they can maintain personal
day-to-day supervision.
Several thousand of the scant
European population of 42,000
have worked and fought against
terrorism in various branches of i
the security forces—many of them
as volunteers. But the strain, fi
nancial losses, and the knowledge
that Mau Mau terrorism may con
; tinue for years has combined to
produce a marked lack of enthus
iasm for further conscripted ser
vice.
No less than 130 out of 206 Eu
ropeans called up in July and 100
out of 114 called up in August
have appealed against having to
do full-time service, and there is
general sympathy throughout the
colony for those men who already
have completed several years’ ser
vice in the British Army, Navy,

since World War II.
To encourage immigrants and
insure that they are given the
chance to get settled, all new ar*
rivals in the colony are given a
period of two years in which they
are not liable to be conscripted.
The the continuance of the
emergency with few signs it will
end quickly is daunting hundreds
of prospective new settlers from
Britain.
One businessman here said re
cently: “We want new staff, new
blood from Britain, but prospective
candidates are unwilling to face
the possibility of being required
to serve in the Army or police at
the end of their first two years
here, just as they are beginning to
make headway in their jobs.”
Any large scale criticism of the
European community's alleged lack
of enthusiasm to do compulsory
service is met here quickly by ac
cusations made against the Asian
population. And the fact is that
the registration and call-up of
Asian manpower have been a woe
ful disappointment.
Dr. S. G. Hassan, director of
Asian manpower, has disclosed
that 30 per cent of Asians ignore
call-up notices served on them,
and many never can be traced.
Seven or eight out of every 100
Asians sent call-up notices, only 10
are found fit for service.
Only 650 Asians are serving in
Army, police, or with civil author
ities as a result of the call-up, al
though registration figures dis
close that there are 11,000 Asians
; in Kenya eligible for the draft.
Contrasting with this picture oi
too few men for the fighting and
ancillary services is set the tre
mendous reserve of manpower en
joyed by the loose-knit, amorphous
terrorist bands, who still are able
to force thousands of Kikuyr
tribesmen to help them in raids
on farms and attacks on Army
police, and Kikuyu guard posts.

Dr. Bogle, who took his M. A.
and Ph.D. degrees at Boston Uni
versity, has published six articles
on the socio-economic history of
New Albany, Indiana, in the “In
diana Magazine of History.” A
graduate of Eastern Illinois State
College, Dr. Arzeni took his M. S.
and Ph.D. degrees at the Univer
sity of Michigan. His thesis was
recently published in its entirety
in the “American Midland Natur
alist.” He has published articles
in the “Bryologist” and his labora
tory manual is now in use at the
University of Michigan. Before
comnig to Tougaloo Southern
Christian College, Dr. Arzeni spent
two years in Liberia as researchr
botanist for the Firestone Planta
tions Co. and had taught at Albion
College in Michigan.
Formerly an assistant professor
of physical education at Bethune
Cookman College, Daytona Beach,
Fla., Mr. Braxton has also served
as athletic director and head coach
at Tilltoaon College, Austin, Texas,
i where he turned out two champion
ship track teams and successful
football and basketball teams.
Braxton coached football teams
won two state championships at
i the Industrial High School, Fair
1 field, Alabama. He took his M.A.
degree in physical education at
New York University. Dr. Palmer
took his Ph.D. at Columbia Uni
; versity and also holds a degree
in education from the University of
Alabama. Miss Thompson did her
j undergraduate work at North Caro
lina College, Durham, and is a
candidate for an M.S. in physical
| education there.
Mrs. Townsend, who becomes the
new head of the English Depart
ment, is completing work for the
Ph.D. degree at the University of
Pittsburgh. Dr. Borinski, who re
i cently took his Ph.D. degree at the
same institution, has written an
article on "The Sociological and
Legal Interpretation of the Su
preme Court Decision of March 17,
1954,” which will appear in the
“Pittsburgh Law Review.” He
plans to resume the Social Science
Forums, which have gained state
wide recognition in dealing with
current issues of regional and na
l tional importance.
! Assisting Coach Braxton with
the football squad will be Mr.
Wilbert Qwens, who is also an in
structor of physical education at
the Tougaloo Preparatory School.
A recent graduate of Bethune
Cookman College, Mr. Owens was
an All-Conference right end and
1 editor of student publications.
J The incoming freshman class.
which numbers more than 100 stu
! dents, was recently put through a
| battery of tests designed to mea
sure different aptitudes. The class,
I one of the most heterogeneous in
{ the institution’s history, includes
: residents of Alabama, Tennessee,
j Virginia, Connecticut and New
York. Most of the freshmen come
I from Mississippi and more live in
Jackson than in any other city
The newcomers will don red and
! blue freshman caps early this week
; as they settle down to regular cam
! pus routine.
$60,000 has been spent during
the summer months on renovating

RAKENNUSRAHASTON KERÄYS
JATKUU MENESTYKSELLA
Kuluneen viikon aikana on
rakennusrahaston keräys taas
kin kulkenut eteenpäin hyväs
sä tahdissa. Matkustaminen
kyllä on ollut vähän vaikeaa
talven myrskyjen ja liukkait
ten teitten vuoksi, mutta yhtä
matkaa lukuunottamatta on
kuitenkin voitu noudattaa oh
jelmaa. Past. H. P. Esala on
matkustanut Pohjois-Dakotas
sa ja Minnesotassa ja on saanut
kokea huomattavaa suosiota
asiaa kohtaan.
Matka Port Arthurin ja Fort
" Williamin seudulle jäi pastori
Nopolalta tekemättä. Siihen
oli kaksikin syytä: tiet olivat
jään peittämät, ja sitten kotiin
tuli odottamatonta, vakavaa
sairautta, joten ei ollut mah
dollista lähteä matkalle.
Ensi pyhän aikana on taas
kin tilaisuuksia Ylä-Michigan
issa seuraavasti: past. Esala on
Calumetissa pyhäaamuna, pas
tori Kokkosen järjestelyjen
mukaan. Iltapäivällä on past.
Esala Massissa ja illalla Co
vingtonissa. Past. Nopola on
ensi pyhäaamuna Marquettes
sa saarnaten suomenkielellä
klo 9 ja englanninkielellä klo
11. Chathamissa on tilaisuus
kirkossa klo 2 iltapäivällä.
Ensi viikolla on sitten seu
raavat tilaisuudet: past. Esala
on Amasassa maanantai-ilta
na ja Beechwoodissa tiistai-il
tana. Past. Nopola on Brant
woodissa torstai-iltana ja Ho
peajoella per j a ntai-iltana.
Viikkoillan tilaisuudet alote
taan klo 7:30.
Täyden osuutensa ovat jo
suorittaneet seuraavat seura
kunnat: Ironwood, Wakefield,
Bessemer, North York, Iron
Belt, Lehtijärvi, Sandy ja
Waasa.
Marquette, Michigan
Marraskuun 16 päivä oli
Sion kirkossa kolmiosaiset
paartit pappilan väelle. Oli
kulunut 10 vuotta siitä, kun
pastori Armas L. Mäki alkoi
Marquette Sion Luterilaisen
seurakunnan p a 1 velukseen.
Tämä päivä oli pastorin syn
tymäpäivä ja pastorin ja mrs
Mäen hääpäivä. Ohjelmasta
tässä mainittakoon. Sion kuoro
lauloi kaksi laulua; Armas Lil
jeroosilta juhlapuhe, miss El
len Ojanen johdattaen musiik
ki puolta. Useita muitakin nu
meroita esitettiin, vaan kirjoit
taja ei ole saanut heidän ni
miään. Ohjelman jakajana oli
mrs Arthur Ahonen. Pastori
ja mrs Mäki olivat kovasti yl
lätetyt. Liikutetuin sanoin pas
tori tervehti kirkontäyteistä
yleisöä ja kiitti arvokkaista ta
loustavaroista, jöita oli tuotu
heille lahjaksi tämän merkki
päivän johdosta. Ohjelman jäl
keen siirryttiin alasaliin naut
timaan Ruth kerhon valmista
masta kahvitarjoilusta.
Marraskuun 29 päivä on kä
sitöitten myynti ja säästökan
nujen avaus kirkon alasalissa.
Joilla on kannuja tuokaa ne
tähän tilaisuuteen.
Mrs John Lammi ja mrs
Lauri Helberg ovat muistaneet
Sion seurakunnan kahvikalus
toa kirkon alasalissa lahjoit
taen uusia kahvikuppia. Kiitos
lahjoittajille.
Marraskuun 12 päivänä kuo
li St. Luke’s sairaalassa mrs
Erland Jokinen, Ebenistä. Hä
net haudattiin Swansonin hau
taustoimistosta Park hautaus
maahan. Pastori Frank A. Pel
konen toimitti viralliset tehtä
vät.
Mrs Pete Mäki, Chathamista,
on ollut St. Luke’s sairaalassa
apua saamassa terveydelleen.
Hän on päässyt jo kotiinsa.
Mr ja mrs Albeen Liimatai
nen ovat matkustaneet Arizo
nan valtioon viettämään tal
vikuukausia terveydellisistä
syistä.

$57 miljoonan laina
kuparin kaivamiseen
Jo kauan seisauksissa ollut
White Pine kuparialue, lähellä
Ontonagonia, Ylä-Michiganis
sa, uskottavasti avataan suu
remmalla voimalla aivan lähi
tulevaisuudessa, sillä liittohal
lituksen RFC virasto oh myön
tänyt yli $57 miljoonan lainan
tämän kuparialueen kehityk
seen. Alueella sanotaan olevan
suuret määrät kuparia, jonka
kaivaminen käy välttämättö
mäksi puolustusohjelman syn
nyttämän kuparin puutteen
vuoksi.
Myönnetty laina on annettu
tarkoituksella kehittää kupa
lin kaivaminen White Pine
alueella mahdollisimman no
peaksi ja ajanmukaiseksi.
Stalinin kuvalla var
jeleva voima!
Kommunistipuolueen kes
kuskomitea Budapestissa vah
visti viime viikolla sairastavia
tovereita lupauksella, että
Stalinin kuvalla on parantavia
voimia. Komitean toimistosta
annettiin julkisuuteen vakuu
tus: “Sielun yhteys Stalinin
kanssa on erikoisen tärkeätä
sairaalassa. Varsinkin leikuu
huoneessa pitäisi Stalinin ku
va olla sellaisessa paikassa, et
tä potilas leikkauspöydällä
katselee Stalinia suoraan sil
miin. Potilaan tulee tietää, et
tä Stalin aina suojelee häntä.”
ishpeming, Mich.
Mrs Amanda Toppilan syn
tymäpäivää juhlittiin viime
lauantai-iltana hänen kodis
saan. Hän täytti 75 vuotta sun
nuntaina, marrask. 18 p. Oli
syntymäpäiväkeeki kynttilöi
neen. Mrs Toppila sai paljon
lahjoja. Kuviakin otettiin pöy
dän ympärillä juhlavieraista.
Mrs Toppila on ollut huonon
vointinen jo kauan aikaa,
mutta voi nykyään paremmin.
Mrs Hilda Virtasen luona on
vierajllut hänen poikansa, so
tilas Rolf Virtanen ja hänen
vaimo, jotka ovat hiljattain
menneet avioliittoon.
Mr ja mrs Jack Pelto, Det
roitista, vierailevat mrs Jennie
Laakson luona, West Ishpe
ming.
Mr ja mrs Kust Lofberg ja
mr ja mrs Elis Rantamaa ovat
menneet talveksi Floridaan.

ENSIMMÄISET POHJOLAISET FLORIDAN SAREPTASSA
He lähtivät Michiganin Sa
reptasta Republicista loka
kuun viimeisenä päivänä ja
saapuivat Floridan Sareptaan
Sanfordiin marraskuun kol
mantena. Matkalla pysähdyt
tiin kolmeksi yöksi levähtä
mään ja ajaa köröteltiin nel
jättä päivää. Lähtiessä oli Re
publicissa lunta ja lähdön
edellisenä yönä oli aikamoinen
pyry. Saatoimmekin lähteä sel
laisen talven käsistä harmitte
lematta “soutelemaan” kesäis
tä etelää kohti. Mutta ei se
etelän kesä rientäen vastaan
tullut. Se tuntui aivan kuin
pakenevan edessämme joka
päivä. Lumi tosin loppui Iron
Mountainissa, neljänkymme
nenviiden miilan päässä, mut
ta kylmää tuulta riitti Flori
daan saakka. Pelkäsimme, että
Michiganin talvi seuraisi mei
tä uskollisesti, vaikka aurin
koon asti. Olimme jo Flori
dassa, kun viimeisen matka
päivämme varhaisena aamuna
pysähdyimme kaasua osta
maan. Myyjä ei kiirehtinyt
ulos pienestä pöksästään. Oli
sinhan kyllä voinut soittaa au
ton torvea ja vaikka lähteä
ajamaan heti ja jättää moinen
kyhnyskauppias omaan kyh
nystelyynsä, mutta tilanne
vaati nöyryyttä. Huomaamat

sa, Itäisten kielten valtion kor

000 on joutunut pakenemaan

jolaiset ensimmäisinä asuk

Viimeksi tulleet saimme tulla

Viime päivien neuvottelut
ovat johtaneet Korean sodan
vaiheita hoitavat henkilöt sel
laiseen tulokseen, ettei Korean
sota voi päättyä vielä tämän
kään vuoden jouluksi. Viime
syksynä kenr. MacArthur teki
hyökkäyksen Pohjois-Korean
rajalla olevaa Yalu-jokea koh
ti siinä uskossa, että hän vii
me vuoden jouluun mennessä
valloittaa kommunisteiltä ko
ko Korean. Silloin kiinalaiset
lähettivät vahvasti joukkojaan
Koreaan ja sota sai uutta vauh
tia.
Neuvotteluja rauhasta jat
ketaan, mutta mitään ei vielä
ole saatu lopulliseen ratkai
suun rauhanehtoja koskevis
sa riidanalaisissa kysymyksis
sä.
Synkemmäksi muuttui tilan
ne viikon jamassa, kun YK: n
joukkojen ylikomentaja Ko
reassa, Renr. Ridgway ilmoitti,
että kommunistit ovat surman
neet noin 6,000 amerikkalaista
sotavankia. Ja kommunistit
tietysti heti tekivät syytöksen,
että YK: n joukot ovat sur
manneet noin 17,000 sotavan
kia ja 14,500 siviilihenkilöä se
kä lähettäneet noin tuhat kom
munistia atomipommin kokei
lun uhreiksi.
Monenkaltaisia r a u hantar
jouksia on tehty molemmin
puolin, mutta kaikki ovat ol
leet toiselle puolelle epätyy
dyttäviä.
Taistelut ovat käynnissä rin
tamalla, missä ei ole tapahtu
nut huomattavampaa alueval
loitusta kummankaan puolen
taholta.
Suomen maatalous
väestöä koko kan
sasta 32 pros.
Yleisesti vallitsevat käsityk
set maatalousväestön koko
naismäärästä ja sen suhteelli
sesta osuudesta perustuvat lä
hinnä vuoden 1940 väestötilas
toon. Sen mukaan maatalous
väestöä on 1,901,000 henkeä eli
55.1% maan koko väestöstä.
Uuden väestölaskennan mu
kaan maan koko asukasluku
on 4,028,910 henkeä, siitä maa
laiskunnissa asuvia 2,730,753
eli 67,8%. Ruokakuntia on
väestötilaston mukaan maa
seudulla n. 655,000 ja niistä
maatalousväestön ruokakun
tia 307,850. Viimeksimainittu
jen ruokakuntien väestöluku
on 1,284,000 henkeä. Tämä on
31.9% maan koko väkiluvusta
sekä 47% maaseudulla asuvas
ta väestönosasta. Maatalous
väestö muodostaa näin ollen
kolmanneksen maan koko vä
kiluvusta sekä puolet maaseu
tuväestöstä. (US)
Autojen valmista
mista vähinsä /
rajoitetaan
Koska ensi vuoden aikana
riittää vähemmän terästä si
viilitarpeisiin laajan sotaoh
jelman vaatimuksista, on hal
lituksen taholta ilmoitettu, et
tä ensi vuoden aikana luovu
tetaan terästä noin kolmatta
osaa vähemmän kuin tänä
vuonna.
Muihin vähemmän tarpeelli
siin taloustavaroihin myöskin
annetaan paljon vähemmän te
rästä, kuparia ja aluminia Nii
den tilalla on käytettävä etu
päässä plastiikista valmistet
tuja korvikkeita.

The French Horn.
The French horn or cor de chasse Is
regarded by some musicians as the
sweetest and mellowest of all the wind
Instruments. In Beethoven's time It
was little else than the old hunting
horn, which, for the convenience of the
mounted hunter, was arranged in spiral
convolutions, to be slipped over the
head and carried resting on one shoul
der and under the opposite arm. The
Germans still call it the waldhorn?
that is, "forest horn."

Just as good as betting on a sure thing
that a fight will disrupt the friendship
of at least two members and perhaps
cause loss to the management for that
week.

! JUSTICE HORACE GRAY DEAD.
! He Retired Last Spring ? Brief Sketch
of Career.
Lynn, Mass., Sept 16? Justice
Horace Gray, who retired from the
United States supreme bench last
spring, died at his residence in Na
hant yesterday morning of paralysis.
He had been in ill health for some
time. Since his retirement he had
been staying at his summer home.
Judge Gray was born in Boston,
March 24, 1828, and was graduated
from Harvard college in the class o!
1843 and from t?he law school in 1849
He was admitted to the bar in 1851.
He was reporter of the superior ju
dicial court of Massachusetts from
1854 to 1861. He was appointed asso
ciate justice of that court in 1864 and
chief justice in 1873. President Ar
thur commissioned him as associate
justice of the supreme court of the
United States, Dec. 19, 1881.
On Aug. 11 of this year he resigned
on account of ill health. In his place
President Roosevelt appointed Hon.
Oliver Wendell Holmes, chief justice
of the supreme court cf Massachu
setts. With the exception of Justice
Harlan, Justice Gray had served on
the United States supreme bench
longer than any other member.
Oyster Bay. n. Y., Sept. 16. ? When
informed of the death of former Jus
tice Gray, cf the supreme court, who
died yesterday, President Roosevelt
said:
"I had a high and peculiar respect
for Justice Gray. I felt that he had
done the greatest possible service as
justice, and I deeply mourn his death.
I am deeply shocked and grieved."

Leomlnftter'ii Old Ducking Stool.
In the o!d Priory church of Leomin
ster is n very interesting specimen of
the old cucking or ducking stool, a uni
versal mode of punishment of scolds,
scandal mongers -and women with too
long a tongue. It was ulso inflicted on
brewers and bakers, etc.. transgressing
the law, who in such a stool were im
mersed over head and ears in stercorc
(stinking water). This mode of pun
ishment dates Ixiek to Saxon times,
and the Leominster specimen \vas the
last used in England of which we have
any record in 1S0D. Several other spec
imens still exist about the country. &a
at Montgomery. Warwick, Fordwich
and Leek e.? Travel.

Declins to Value All Property at Actual Cash Value and
Says Such Action Would Injure Interests of Territory
Praises Governor Curry and C. V. Safford and
Points Out Work for the Attorneys.
rs i ,iii
Before adjourning at noon today
the members of the Board of
Equalization have rejected the rec
ommendation contained in the report
of the district attorneys of the Terri
tory and the resolutions adopted by
them during the convention at the
capitol held January 6 to have all
property valued at actual cash value
declaring that if the recommendation I
were followed the board believes it
would "result disastrously to the in
terests of the Territory."
The board declares that while the
district attorneys ask that all prop
erty be valued at actual cash value
vet there seems to have been no pro

board's opinion is a condition "prece

of the board.
The following is an official extract
from the minutes of the board which
is still in session:
"We have received the report of
the district attorneys and the resolu
tions as adopted by them, during the
convention assembled at the Capitol,
on the 6th. inst. We have given them
due consideration and much thought,
as coming from so distinguished and
able body of officials.
"They ask us. to value all property
at an actual cash value, and give us
erty was assessed at actual cash
value, the assessment would be more
equitable. Why would this be the
case? Would the district attorneys
enforce the laws belter under the
new condition than the old? Who de
termines the cash value? The district
auoineyo, me 0r the own
ers?
"We have been at a loss to deter
mine why this matter was brought up
at this time.
lattire. The legislature failed to
make any appropriation, for the use
of the board, for this purpose. How
ever, we endorse and appreciate the
good intention of the Governor and
the tax commission and recommend
that it be continued and the fullest
investigation be had.
After due consideration we have
concluded to reject the recommenda
tion of the district attorneys, as we
1 that it would result disastrously
the interests of the Territory."

These celebrated Hot Springs are j
located, in the midst of the Ancient
Cliff Dwellings, twenyt-five miles west
of Taos" and fifty miles north of Santa
Fe, and about twelve miles from Bar
anco Station, on the Denver and Rio
Grande Railroad, from which point a
daily line of stage runs to the springs.
The temperature of these waters is
from 90 to 122 degrees. The gases are
carbonic. Altitude G.000 feet. Climate
very dry and delightful the entire
year round. There is now a commod
ious hotel for the convenience of in
valids and tourists. People suffering
from consumption, cancer and other
contagious diseases, are not accepted.
These waters contain 1,026.24 grains
of alkaline salts to the gallon, being
the richest alkalin Hot Springs in the
world. The efficiency of these waters
has been throughly tested by the
miraculous cures attested to in the
following diseases: Paralysis, Rheu
matism, Neuralgia, Malaria, Brighfs
Disease of the Kidneys, Syphilitic
and Mercurial Affections, Scrofula,
Catarrh, La Grippe, all Female Com
plaints, etc. Board, lodging and bath
ing $2.50 per day; $15 per week; $50
per month. Stage meets Denver
trains and waits for Santa Fe train
upon request. This resort is attrac
tive at all seasons and is open all
winter. Passengers for Ojo Caliente
can leave Santa Fe at 9 a. m. and
reach Ojo Caliente at 5 p. m., the

BROTHER HERMES. President
assessed at all in Bernalillo county,
by reason of no plat or survey having
been made of same. We call their
attention to the fact that the county
commissioners, have authority of law
to have these surveys and plats made.
"The experience of the few states,
which have adopted the plan, as sug
gested to us, as far as we are able
to ascertain, has been such that it
would not seem the part of wisdom
for us to adopt it.
"If the board is asked to assume
the grave responsibility of raising
values, it should also have the power
to reduce the rates correspondingly.
"It has been the policy of this
board in the past, and it is their pres
ent aim and intention to make, as near
as possible, an equal valuation upon
an classes of property, so that they;
would Dear a unitorm, fair and just
proportion of value as between all
interests.
Commendable Promise.
"We are very glad to receive the
assurance from the district attorneys,
as set forth in their resolutions, that
they intend fully to enforce the as
sessing and tax collecting laws, in
their respective districts in the fu
ture. This promise indeed is very
commendable
"From the records of our board
and statistics placed before us by the
traveling auditor, we have no hesitan
cy In saying, that there has never
been a more uniform and equitable
assessment than the past year, and
that in the history of the Territory it
has never been in so good a financial
condition. Collections have improv
ed from an average of 60 per cent to
about 85 per cent. We attribute this
partly to the fixing of values by this
board and largely the systematic and
intelligent effort on the part of Trav
eling Auditor Safford and the active
interest taken in these matters by
Governor Curry. As fine as this con
dition appears to be, there is still
great room for improvement. We find
that in some of the counties the as
sessors do not list a considerable por-
I tion of the property at any value and
I we feel that it is the duty of the dis-
trict attorneys to call the attenlon of
i the assessors to this condition, so that
in future, there will be no grounds for
complaint on this score. .
Recommends Investigation.
"We have received the report of the
tax commission appointed by the
Governor in December, in which they
state, that on account of the limited
time, they were unable to investigate
or report upon conditions. They rec
ommend that this board visit the vari
ous counties for purposes of investi
gation, during the year or that a
commission 'be appointed by the board
of equalization for this purpose, and
that report" be made to the Governor,
before the next session of the legis-
secretary of the interior, to investi
gate and report upon the inauguration
of a rational forest policy for the
lands of the United States, and thus
helned to lav the foundation of the
nation's present forest policy, which
he was shortly to become the chief
agent in developing.
Forest Reserves.
As a result of the commission's re
port, 11 new western forest reserves
were created, with a total area of over
21,000,000 acres, and legislation was
enacted by Congress in 1897, defining
the purposes for which forest re
serves should be created, and provid
ing for their administration by the de
partment of the interior. The coni'
mission also recommended tne- putting
into forest reserves all lands more
valuable for the production of timber
than for agriculture, and a policy pro
viding for the immediate use of the
forests by the public, as well as their
production for the benefit of the fu
ture. .
On July 1, 1898, Mr. pinchot was
appointed chief of the division of
forestry in the United States departr
ment of agriculture, and here con
fronted him the dual task of bringing
tne rmblic to a realization of the
economic Importance of forest preser
vation, and gathering the technical
knowledge and staff necessary to put
forestry into actual practice in the
United States. There were then less
than 10 professional foresters in the
country and no science or literature
of American forestry was in existence
while little practical work in thi
direction had as yet been attempted
by the division,
The broadening activity of the lat
ter led to its reorganization as the
"bureau of forestry" July 1, 1901. On
February 1, 1905, the administration
of the forest reserves was transferred
by act of Congress from the depart
ment of the interior to the depart
ment of agriculture. The development
of all their resources now began In
earnest, and the bureau became the
"forest service." Under Mr. Pinchot's
guidance the policy originally recom
mended by the committee of 1897 was
practically carried to conclusion, and
to make clear the purpose of secur
ing their fullest use the forest re
serves were now designated as "na
tional forests." The growth of the
service is illustrated by the increase
of its expenditures from $28,520 in
1899 to $3,894,370 In 1909; while Its
receipts, of which there were none
in the first named year, grew to $1,
765,000, in 1909. These are derived
largely from the sale of mature tim
ber, and the charges for private com
mercial uses of the land, such as
grazing.
Mr. Pinchot is worth several mil
lions of dollars in his own right. He
Is unmarried. El Paso Herald.
