DEPOSED CHIEF FORESTER PINCHOT
■ Pinchot, Hi fiord, forester, was born
at Simsbury. Conn.. Aug. 11, 1865,
sot of James and Mary E (Eno)
Plahcot, and grandson of Constantino
Ojril Desire Pinchot, a native of Bre
tenil, France, who, for his political
faith, came to America in 1815, set-
Ming at Milford, Pa., where he be
came a merchant with large western
interests. Gifferd Pinchot attended
Phillips Exeter Academy, and was
graduated at Yale university in 1889
His love of the woods was a passion
from childhood, and while he found
time to captain the college football
team, and carried off several of the
most coveted of the college prizes, he
also won for himself the reputation
•f being *'mad on trees." Deciding
to take up forestry in October, 1889,
ho went to England to consult with
the men best able to direct his stud
ies. As a result of his observations
and after having spent some time in
examining tbe forestry exhibit at tbe
Paris exposition he entered the Ecole
Nationale Forestiere at Nancy. Early
in 1890 he began field work in the
French Alps and the Vosges, and af
ter further study in Switzerland,
Germany and Austria, returned to
America. In IS9I he traveled in
Arizona, Arkansas, California, Ore
gon, Washington and British Colum
bia, and aided in the preliminary ex
amination of George Vanderbilt's for
reat at Biltmore, N. C, where, in Janu
ary, 1892, he began the first sys
tematic forest work done in the Uni
ted States. In December, 1891, he
opened an office in New York City,
as consulting forester, and was en
gaged for the next three years in
miscellaneous work in various sec
tions of the country. He was a mem
ber of the commission appointed by
the National Academy of Science in
1896. at the request of the secre
tary of the interior, to investigate
and report upon the inauguration of
a rational forest policy for the lands
•f the United States, and thus helped
to lay the foundation of the nation's
present forest policy, which he was
shortly to become the chief agent inj
developing. As a result of the com
mission's report, 11 new western for
est reserves were created with a total
area of over 21,000,000 acres, and
legislation was enacted by congress
in 1897. defining the purposes for
which forest reserves should be cre
ated, and providing for their admin
istration by the department of the
interior. The commission also re
commended the putting into forest
reserves all lands more valuable for
Uie production of timber than for
agriculture, and a policy providing
. for the immediate use of the forests \
( by the public, as well as their produc
tion for the benefit of the future. On
.Inly t, 1898, Mr. Pinchot was ap
pointed chief of the division of for
estry in the United States department
•f agriculture, and here confronted
him the dual task of bringing the
public to a realization of the eco- j
nomic importance of forest preserva
tion, and gathering the technical
knowledge and staff necessary to put
forestry into actual practice in the
United States. There were then less
than ten professional foresters in the
•ountry and no science or literature
of American forestry was in eistence,
while little practical work in this di
rection had as yet been attempted by
the division. The broadening activity
•f the latter led to its reorganization
as the "bureau of forestry" July 1,
1901. On Feb. 1, 1905, the admin
istration of the forest reserves was
transferred by act of congress from
tbe department of the interior to the
department of agriculture. The de
velopment of all their resources now
began in earnest, and the bureau be
came the "forest service." Under Mr.
Pinchot's guidance the policy origin
ally recommended by the committee
of 1897 was practically carried to
conclusion, and to make clear the
purpose of securing their fullest use
the forest reserves were now desig
nated as "national forests." The
growth of the service is illustrated
by the increase of its expenditures
from $28,520 in 1899 to $3,894,370
In 1909; while its receipts, of which
tbere were none in the first-named
year, grew to $1,765,000 In 1909.
These are derived largely from the
sale of mature timber, and the
charges for private commercial uses
of the land, such as grazing and the
development of water power. The
aggregate area of public land in the
national forests increased from 40,-
--866,154 acres in 1898 to 194,505,325
in 1909, and althbugh the expendi
ture for these lands is still much
lower than in other countries, their
usefulness has been greatly increased,
and devastation from forest fires
minimized. Also, in 1899 be had
but 11 assistants, and ten years later,
in 1909, there were nearly 2,000. The
territory under his control is more
than five times the size of New Eng
land, and the vast machinery of the
forest service is regarded as the best
example of economical, energetic, ef
fective and scientific work in the en
tire executive department of the gov
ernment. The house committee which
investigated the expenditures, meth
ods and results in 1908, reported
that the sandard of the forest service
was fully on a par with the methods
of the outside business world and su
perior to any other part of the public
service. Mr. Pinchot was a member
of the commission on public lands of
the United States, appointed by Presi
dent Roosevelt in 1903, the work of
which formed the basis for the presi
dent's subsequent recommendations
to congress concerning public land
questions. In 1903 he was a member
of the committee on the organization
of government scientific work; in
1 905 he served on the committee on
department methods, appointed by
President Roosevelt to increase the
administrative efficiency of all depart
ments; in 1907 on the inland water
ways commission, appointed by tbe
president at his suggestion, for the
improvement of the navigation in the
Mississippi valley; and in 1908 on the
commission on country life, also ap
pointed by the president. The con
servation movement headed by Mr.
Pinchot attained wide public recog
nition in May, 1908, when, at the
suggestion of the inland waterways
commission, the president called a
conference of the governors of all
.stateß and territories to meet at the
White House to discuss the question,
an unprecedented proceeding in the
history of the country. In his ad
dress at the preliminary meeting
President Roosevelt said: "I want to
say here that if it had not been for
Gifford Pinchot this conference never
would or never could have been held."
Before adjournment this conference
adopted a declaration of principles
regarding the wise use of all natural
resources. On June 8, 1908, the
president, in line with one of the
recommendations made by the gover
nors, appointed the national con
servation commission "to co-operate
with the states in order to conserve
the natural resources of our whole
country." This commission was or
ganized in four sections to consider
the four great classes of resources—
waters, forests, lands and minerals,
with the members of the inland wa
terways commission forming the sec
tion of waters, and Mr. Pinchot as
chairman of the commission. It re
ported to the president Jan. 1, 1909,;
and on Jan. 22, 1909, tbe president
sent a special message to congress
transmitting the report, which dealt
with the present extent and condition
of natural resources and the means
of conserving them. Following the
adoption by congress of an amend
ment to the sundry civil bill for 1909,
which terminated effective co-opera
tion between the commission and the
executive departments, the work of
co-operating with the 42 state con
servation commissions and the 51 j
great national organizations which I
have appointed conservation commit
tees (Dec. 1, 1909) was assumed by>
the joint committee on conservation
appointed by a joint conference of!
the governors and the organizations, j
Mr. Pinchot is chairman of this joint'
committee. The North American con-!
servation conference was held at the'
White House in January, 1909, tof
consider the means of international'
co-operation to secure conservation!
of the resources of the North Ameri-j
can continent as a whole. Invitations |
were delivered to the president of;
Mexico and the governor-general of,
Canada by Mr. Pinchot in person, act
ing as representative of the president,J
and Mr. Pinchot was also one of the
United States commissioners and the
chairman of the conference. In addi
tion to adopting a declaration of prin
ciples, the commissionerss - recom
mended that a conference be held at
The Hague to consider the conserva
tion of world resources. As the next
logical step in the conservation move
ment the National Conservation Asso-|
ciation was finally formed, Oct. 9,1
1909, with Dr. Charles W. Eliot.!
president emeritus of Harvard uni
versity, as president. Membership in
this association is open to every
American citizen. Its object is to carry
into practice the principles of con
servation as they were declared by
the governors' conference of 1908 at
the White House. In 1902. Mr. Pin
chot made a tour of inspection in the
Philippines to report on a forest pol
icy for the islands.
, "What Is Ice Cream?" is Query in
Chicago.
Chicago. Jan. B.—"What is ice!
cream?"
This question is likely to become!
as famous in Chicago as President]
Taft's "What is whisky?"
The newly appointed state food
commission, with Dr. T. J. Bryan, I
state analysist. began their sessions!
here yesterday and ice cream and
evaporated milk are the first two sub-;
jects to be considered.
The question to be decided is
whether the frozen delight contain-1
ing gelatine is "ice cream." Gelatine:
say the manufacturers and their ex- j
perts, does not harm the product, j
but on the other hand, adds to its!
nutrition.
Therefore they wish to use gela
tine as a preservative in ice cream,
but do not wish to inform the pub
lic that they use gelatine.

RUSSIAN CHURCHMEN—Metropolitan Nicholas, second
ranking Russian Orthodox prelate and head of an eight
man delegation visiting the United States, chats at the
Washington Cathedral with fellow delegate Archbishop Gus
tav Turs of Riga, head of the Evangelical Lutheran Church
of Latvia.—Star Staff Photo.
Eight Russian Clergymen
Feted on Visit in Capital
An eight-man delegation of Russian clergymen, headed by
Metropolitan Nicholas, second-ranking Soviet Orthodox prelate,
arrived in town yesterday
They spent a leisurely morning and part of an afternoon
sightseeing before being feted last night at a dinner at the Cleve-.
land Park Congregational Church.
At the church they were welcomed in a brief address by DrJ
Walter W. Van Kirk of Mount
Vernon, N. Y.. executive director,
Department of International Af
fairs. of the National Council of
Churches, sponsors of the visit.
Dr. Van Kirk was one of a
United States nine-man delega
tion of churchmen that recently
visited Russia.
End U. S. Visit June 13
Dining their stay in the
United States, begun June 2 and
ending June 13, the Russian
group will confer with officials of
the council and seek better rela
tions between the Russian and
American clergy.

directed Virginia or any locality,
therein to permit white and
Negro pupils to attend the same

Senator McCue said members

Charles Loridans,
French Consul
ATLANTA, June 9 UP).—
Charles Loridans, 78. French
consul in Atlanta for many years
and a construction engineer,
died today.
He was bom at Tourcoing,
France, July 20, 1877, and re
ceived a civil engineering degree
in 1896 from the Ecole Nationale
des Arts et Metiers at Challons-
Sur-Marne. Mr. Laridoans be
jcame a United States citizen in
{l9lß. He served as consular agent
I for France since 1928 with the
exception of the years when the
country was occupied by the
{Axis powers.

items.ocr_eng:
1935 State Convention May Open Kacey Golden Jubilee
Sheridan Council’s
Delegates To 1934
Session Plan Drive
Local Knights to Start 50th Anniversary Celebration
in April, 1935—Robinson, McDonald
Elected State Delegates
Bitorts to bring the annual state
convention of the Knights of Co
lumbus to Waterbury In 1935 will
be launched by Sheridan council's
delegates to this year's convention
scheduled for May. Delegates to
the 1934 session were elected at a
meeting held last night in the
Knights of Columbus rooms on
Grand street.
Grand Knight John F. Robinson
and Past Grand Knight Charles E.
McDonald were chosen to repre
sent Sheridan council at the com
ing state convention. Alternates
elected were Financial Secretary
Mortimer Connor and Deputy
Grand Knight Cornelius F. Ma
loney.
Convention. Jubilee Coincide
Inasmuch aH the state conven
tion In 1935 will coincide with the
opening of Sheridan council’s
golden jubilee, officers and mem
bers arc earnestly working towards
a program that will begin with the
state convention and Include many
more outstanding features through
out the 50th anniversary year.
Sheridan council was founded
April 27, 1885, and the supremo
council at New Haven notified of
the formation of a new council in
Waterbury. Formal election of of
ficers ar\d initiation were conduct
ed on May 3, 1886. Inasmuch as
the state convention is always held
In May it will form a fitting open
ing to the golden jubilee of Sheri
dan council If state officers and
delegates from other councils
throughout the state approve the
plan.
Special Agent Present
John Dailey, special agent of the
supreme council, was present at
last night’s meeting and following
the regular course of business de
livered' an instructive and Inspir
Ing address on Columblanism and
the need of a strong organization
such as the Knights of Columbus
at this time. x
Reports on the recent boyology
institute conducted in Waterbury
by Sheridan council under the di
rection of Stephen Murray from
the supreme council Boy life bu
reau elicited the information that
a circle of Columbian Squires wifi
be formed in Waterbury shortly.
By vote of the council last night
the snpretpe office will bo formully
notified of Sheridan council’s appli
cation for sponsirship of a circle
in Waterbury.
Villon Named Chairman
George Dillon was named chair
man of the annual communion
breakfast. It will be held the Sun
day preceding Trinity Sunday.
The first and second degrees will
be conferred on a class of candi
dates at the second meeting of the
council in April to be followed by
the major degree on the Sunday
falling nearest to the datts of the
foundation of Sheridan council,
which occurred April 27, 1885.
Lecturer Patrick Wallace report
ed on the progress made by the
Kacey ball committee. The dance
will be held the first week in May.
FULL WEATHER REPORT
» -
Boston, Mar. 22—(UP)—Weather
forecast:
Massachusetts and Rhode Island
—Fair and cold tonight. Friday In
creasing cloudiness followed by
snow Friday night.
Connecticut — Fair and colder to
night. Friday increasing cloudi
ness followed by snow Friday night.
RETURNS TO HADLEY’S
RAYMOND LKGGETT
Raymond I»-KlteUi well known In
Waterbury for the |»st JO years as
a member of the staff of Hadley’s
Furniture store, has rejoined the
stuff there In an executive capacity.
Mr jLcggett, who lias been In the
furniture business for 15 years. Is u
native of Waterbury, and with the
exception of x short period spent
out of town, hus always been em
ployed In the city. During Ills serv
ice with Hadlev’s he has built np a
large circle of friends who will be
glad to hear of his return to the
store.
Find ‘Father of Oregon’s’
Naturalization Papers
Oregon City, Ore, <CP)—Na
turalization papers of Dr John Mc
Loughlln, "Father of Oregon,” were
discovered in vaults of the- county
recorder's office here.
Dr McLoughlin, factor of the
British Hudson Buy Fur company,
befriended American settlers in
Oregon in early days. When the
fur post was discontinued, after
Oregon was ceded to the United
States, Dr McLoughlin remained
and took a farm.
The naturalization papers were
issued by the second district court
of Oregon territory, Sept 5, 1851.
To be
perfectly
frank
about it. •
A “MIDDISHADE” BLUE .SUIT
*352
CAN’T. HELP BEING THE BEST >35 SUIT
THE WORLD OF GOOD CLOTHES KNOWS
That’* why it’* a “Middishade” — the only reason for its being — and incidentally,
the same price as in 1932 and ’33.
The clothes world wasn’t short of $35 suits, when This famous sint faced the lime
light — but — they were short of the kind of $35 suits the Middishade is.
Today, “Middishade” $35 suits are known from Maine to California, as the stan
dard by which all $35 suits are judged.
Which, to us, is reason enough why $35 “Middishade” blue suits are here — and
here only.
Diocesan Bureau Has
Splendid Ally In Club
Intercollegiates Render Financial Aid In Sponsoring
Social Events—Annual Ball April 2
The efforts of the Intercollegiate
Club of Waterbury to give some fi
nancial assistance to the Diocesan
Bureau of Social Service bring to
gether two Catholic organizations,
one young, determined and Idealis
tic, the other old, established and
none the less Idealistic/
Both are examples of Catholic
Action, action that Is broad, valu
able and constructive. The club,
composed of college graduates and
undergraduates, brings together
Catholics from all parts tff the city,
regardless of college af.^lation, in
to a harmonious whole that aims
to be a cultural, educational and
civic force when its possibilities
are realized.
The Diocesan Bureau Is such a
striknng asset to the community
that Waterbury could ill afford to
be without. Its service is so
widespread, so thorough and effee-,
live, that too few people realize
that it was one of the most im
portant agencies in bringing Water
bury through the financially and
socially trying times of depression
and distress.
The Waterbury office of the bur
eau was established in 1920, when
It was clearly evident that there
was a need here for social and so
cialized service. Since Its beginning
here, the work it has done has
been eminently and definitely suc
cessful.' It has not confined Itself
to the cold-blooded giving of finan
cial help, but has sought, and
quite successfully, to remember
that Its "cases” are persons, real
human beings, and to treat them
as such.
Family cases, as in the other
seven cities of the state where they
are handled by the bureau, have
been more numerous and more try
ing than ever during recent years,
but they have ail been given the
personal attention, the humanized
care and ail the possible assis
tance of tile bureau through its
workers. Children's cases and child
welfare have loomed, and still
loom, strong on the bureau's horl
zon, for It is with the youngsters
that the most constructive work is
possible.
The many branches into which
it sends Itself muke it hard to re
alize that the Diocesan Bureau
needs the moral and financial sup
port of at least the Catholic pub
lic if it is to carry on. Its service
is so extensive, and carried on so
thoroughly, that even the employ
ment of strict economy does not
relieve the bureau of its need for
funds.
it was with this last thought
in mind, and with a vista of real
Catholic service before them, that
in the winter of 1932-33, a group
of young people made plans to
band together as a Catholic col
lege club. As an experimental ven
ture it was thought best to hold
a Charity Ball, with the Dtoeesan
Bureau to receive the proceeds.
Working together the handicaps
of partisanship, loyalty to individ
ual colleges and more or less cas
ual dismissal of their ideas, the
members of the little group worked
earnestly anj long at plans for the
city's first Catholic intercollegiate
venture. Their efforts were reward
ed when the Charity Ball was an
outstanding success and several
hundred dollars turned over to the
diocesan bureau.
Convinced by the success of
their original attempt that an Inter
collegiate club could perform ser
vice to the community and could
band together young men and
women for a common purpose, the
organizers continued to make their
plans gradually and effectively.
Stressing the club’s social side in
order to break down any possible
resistance of potential candidates
for membership, the intercollegiate
group won itself more and more
support. Definite organization was
decided on at a meeting in the
summer of 1933 and members be
gan to flock to the standard. The
title of the Intercollegiate Club of
Waterbury was chosen as a fitting
one.
In the first week of September,
1933, the Intercollegiate Club's
charter members read and adopted
a constitution and set of by-laws.
Thus was begun a new and prom
ising organzation, one whose fu
ture can be one of definite and
valuable service to its members, its
city and its church.
The proceeds of the 19 34 Inter
collegiate Ball scheduled to be held
at Hamilton Park on Easter .Mon
day evening, will also be donated
to the Diocesan bureau.
GIFTS OF SILVER
FROM ASSOCIATES
Feature Dinner Party
in Honor of Dr Pond,
Former Director
Dr Millicent Pond, former head
of the Federal re-employment ac
tivities In Connecticut, was guest
of honor at a dinner given at the
Dawn Club last night in New Ha
ven. Dr Pond addressed members
of the Rotary club here Tuesday
at their luncheon meeting at the
Elton.
She was presented with a gift of
silver by managers and adminis
trative officials of the State and
Federal employment services.
Dr Pond was loaned to the gov
ernment by the Scovlll Manufac
turing Company for the purpose of
organizing the service, returning
to her duties here March 1, to be
succeeded by Major Leonard J.
Maloney. *
C. U. BOYSSEEK
PARIS ART PRIZE
Four Compete With 36
Other College Students
in Rreliminaries
Washington, D. C.—Four Cath
olic university architectural stu
dents, Vernon F. Duckett, S.
Thomas Htathes, John L. R. Grand
and John M. Baer, Jr, carried the
hopes of the university as they
competed with thirty-six others
from major universities, colleges
and private ateliers throughout the
country in the second preliminary
trials for the 27 th Beaux Arts
Paris prize held last week.
Each student was handed a
sealed problem at 9 o’clock in the
morning and locked in his room
for twenty-four consecutive hours
to design a group plan of build
ings on a small scale.
A supervisor remained on guard
to see thut no advice, criticism, or
assistance of any kind was given
and the competitors either took
tlielr meals in their loges or went
out in a body.
The drawings were taken from
them at 9 o'clock the following
morning and mailed to New York
to await the jury's decision. In
this Judgment eight of the forty
contestants will be selected as tin -
alists.
This scholarship of $9.600 and
all expenses at the Ecole Nationale
des Beaux Arts in Paris is open
to any citizen of the United States
under 27 years of age. The year
1928 saw Dr Thomas H. Locraft,
now a member of the teaching
staff of the department of archi
tecture. victorious in the linals of
the Paris prize over three Yale
university students.
Professor Frederick V. Murphy,
head of tho department has been
stressing preparatory work on plan
study during the past month. Of
this quartet of Washington stu
dents, Duckett, Stathes and Grand
are holders of the Beaux Art In
stitute Certificate which exempted
them from the initial contest. Baer,
a sophomore, was one of ton chos
en from a Held of 600 over the en
tire country in the first preliminary
six weeks ago. His drawing, be
cause of Its exceeding merit entitl
ed him to enter the next prelimin
ary.
STUDY STERILIZATION
Berlin (UP).—During the period
between August 1, 1932, and July
31, 1938, all patlents^it the psy
chiatric clinic in Rostock have
been examined In order to estab
lish whether their affliction was
hereditary, thus involving sterili
zation under tho new law. It was
found that out of a total of 741,
268. or nearly 36 per cent, of the
patients proved eligible for sterili
zation. This group, however, in -
I eluded 64 cases in which the ne
I cesslty of sterilization was not
1 established beyond doubt.
FLYER AT INQUIRY
Among the aviation notables at
the Senate airmail Investigation at
Washington was Jimmy Wedell,
the famous sia-ed flyer, shown here
at a heating. Wedell Is a partner
In an air service at Shreveport, l*a.
Traffic Instructor Right
At Home With Model
Laltewood, Ohio, (UP)—Officer
G. H. Campbell. Lakewood's in
structor in traffic safety, was
haled before Police Chief L. B.
Miller recently. On the chief’s
desk was a moving picture pro
jection machine.
“I thought maybe you might be
able to use this in your school lec
tures. The auto club has some ac
cident prevention reels. Think
you can learn to operate it?”
"Can I learn to operate it?”
Campbell repeated. “I owned a
theater in Akron for five years
and dropped $1?,000 in it when I
closed up and joined the force
here eight years ago.”
15,981 Pairs Of Shoes 1
Distributed To Needy
— ■«
Mutual Aid Committee Reports Articles Valued at J
$68,355 Feature Relief Work
William M. Harris, chairman of
the Mutual Aid Unemployment
Fund today burned a survey of the
clothing: distribution for the year
1933. This clothing: was furnished
by the American Red Cross. Mutual
Aid Unemployment Fund. Diocesan
Bureau. Waterbury Chapter of the
Needlework Guild of America, Lin
coln House and the Department of
Public Welfare.
The amount spent by this com
munity for clothing, beddings and
shoes, distributed to needy families
was $27,030.08, and the animated

Frank says, according to the

down the stairs leading from the
third floor to the second when he
stumbled and was precipitated the
rest of the way. It was 8:15 at
night on Oct 10, 1933 and the hall

alleges.
The property, a three-story
tenement, is located at 781-789
Bank street. The plaintiff suffered
a fractured right sacri-lllac bone,
lacerated thigh, spinal injuries ai>Q
contused elbow. Ho spent 8 wreeks
in a hospital as the result of his
injuries the complaint says.

Revolt in Mexico.
A military mutiny in Mexico, evi
dently of a political nature, has, it
would seem from latest reports, been
quickly quelled. Three companies of
th® federal troops left their barracks
and undertook to march to strategic
positions, but according to the most
authentic accounts they have been
halted and one report, which still
lacks confirmation, is to the effect
that the two leaders of the revolt.
Gens. Gomez and Serrar.o, have beer,
captured and executed. President
Calles has issued a statement that ex
presses confidence that tne revolu
tion” has been quelled. Gen- Obregon,
former President, has announced his
readiness to take the field In case of
need to support the government
against any uprising.
Both of the leaders of the revolting
troops are candidates for the presi
dency. Serrano has declared himself
in that capacity as the head of the
anti-re-clecUonists or antl-Obregon
forces. There would seem to be co
operation between Gomez and Ser
rano, although they have in a sense
been rivals.
The mutiny of the three companies
that left their barracks may not be
the total of the disaffection In the
Mexican military ranks. Indeed,
there are reports indicating other re
volts. But unless the government at
Mexico City is concealing the full ex
tent of the mutiny there is nothing
on which to base belief that the sit
uation is at a dangerous stage.
It would be deplorable if Mexico
were to suffer another armed rebel
lion. It ha* had a bitter experience
during the past two decades. Revolt
has followed revolt. Civil war has
raged. Countless lives have been lost
and enormous values in property have
been destroyed. With the accession
of Gen. Obregon to the presidency
seemed to have come a period of peace
and of political changes without the
oomplex of militancy. The succession
of President Calles was effected by
orderly process and with another elec
tion at hand the hope was general in
thts country that Mexico would pro
ceed to the change of administration
decreed by the constitution of the re
public without turmoil.
President Calles’ administration has
been one of difficulty. He has had
trouble In internal affairs and com
plication In foreign relations. There
have been some uprisings, notably
among the Yaqul Indians, but they
have been suppressed. This present
revolt is the most serious, but evi
dently the government at Mexico City
has not been taken unawares and is
prepared for the emergency.
. . .... * m+w < —■
It is hinted that Mayor Walker of
New York was sleuthed while having
a joyous jaunt in Europe. Mr. Walker
i® a wise child of the metropolis, who
may be relied on to avoid picking up
acquaintances in resorts where a new
visitor is greeted with "Hello, sucker!”
, w l «*»
It is understood that Mussolini does
not want his name mentioned by any
body excepting himself. Even fame
is capable of being placed on a monop
olistic basi6.
The saddest example of low pay and
overwork is provided by a member of
the grand Jury in a murder district.
Delaying the Decision.
The Commissioners’ action yester
day on the Bureau of Efficiency's rec
ommendations concerning the care of
delinquent or dependent children
awaiting disposition by the courts or
by the Board of Public Welfare is in
the nature of a compromise l*etween
the views of the Bureau of Efficiency
and of those who favor continuing the
jurisdiction over these .children now
maintained by the Police Department
through its Woman's Bureau. The
Bureau of Efficiency had recommended
that children in custody of the Wom
an's Bureau at the House of Detention
be placed immediately under jurisdic
tion of the Board of Public Welfare,
and that remaining moneys of the
House of Detention appropriation be
used to rent one of the Government
dormitory buildings as a receiving
station for these children. An alterna
tive proposal was that the Police De
partment take over this dormitory,
but that the care of children detained
there should be under the Board of
Public Welfare,
The Commissioners decided yester
day to continue the present arrange
ment until Congress acts on a pro
posed recommendation for the estab
lishment of a receiving station for
children, to be maintained by the
Board of Public Welfare.
There will be no disagreement over
the proposal to separate child de
linquents and child dependents from
adults. Facilities at the present House
of Detention prevent as complete a
separation as could be desired, al
though the children and adults occupy
separate floors. There is, in addition,
the psychological effect, which is bad,
of detaining child delinquents and de
■ pendents In the same Institution used
_ las a House of Detention for adult of
f fenders. There should be
separation. &
The present House of Detention will
eoon have to find new quart ere. It Is
I to be hoped that these new quarters
will be selected with a view to per
manency and the provision of those
adequate facilities which the impor
tance of this comparatively new lnstl
r tutlon demands. As for the Jurisdlc
- tion over the children, that is a ques
■ tion which should be decided by the
teetlmony of social experts. There is
no complaint over the nature of the
physical care of the chlldre*n under the
Woman's Bureau. But there Is much
to be said, pro and con, on the whole
matter of Juvenile Institutional care.
Congress no doubt will devote study
to the problem and base its decision
on what experience has taught is best
for the child. The child’s welfar*.
and not a jurisdictional dispute, is the
question at issue.
Pennyworth of Principle.
The gentleman who called at the Dis
trict Building yesterday and protested
against an overcharge of one cent on
his tax bill may possibly have had
called to his attention by now the
saying, "Penny wise, pound foolish.'’
and there already has been used the
altogether uncomplimentary term
"tightwad’’ in connection with the in
cident. But instead of censure this
taxpayer should receive praise. More
power to him! He should insist on the
return of that penny, and there are
many who will wish him success in
his efforts.
The unnamed taxpayer went to Cor
poration Counsel Bride and com
plained. and Mr. Bride offered him a
penny out of his own pocket. In
other words, the taxpayer asked for
bread, and the corporation counsel
gave him a stone. The taxpayer was
right ir. declining Mr. Bride's financial
assistance. As he made it p’-a-n him
self. ;t was not the penny, but a
pennyworth of pr.neipl© uvat ho was
a fey Ana he was ngm!
The explanation of the overcharge
of one cent lies in the custom, familiar
in Government circles, of adding a
penny to a bill in order to divide It
evenly in two Installments. The tax
payer, in the first place, did not know
of this custom. All he knew was that
there had been a mistake In his bill.
There is a saying that if one attends
to the little things the big things will
take care of themselves, and the tax
payer was attending to little things.
He had a perfect right to an explana
tion of why he was asked to pay a
cent more than his due. Nor is the
explanation altogether satisfactory.
Suppose every taxpayer was assessed
one cent additional in order to make
his tax hill divisible by two? The
method would prove an excellent
means of financing a home for aged
auditors, for instance, but it should
not be adopted without the consent
of the taxpayers. And suppose, fur
ther, that instead of adding this
penny, the District had deducted it?
The action of the protesting taxpayer
who demanded his explanation and his
penny yesterday justifies the belief
that if the District had stood the loss
of this cent, the taxpayer would have
been just as quick to show ,up at the
office of Corporation Counsel Bride
and, calling attention to the apparent
error, produce the penny from his
pocket and leave the building—an
honest man!
“Hard Lack.”
“I have been a hard luck kid all
my life,’’ said George Yarrow of
Barnsboro, N. J., as he related to
police the grisly details of his mur
der of sixteen-year-old Rose Sarlo the
other night. Full of self-sympathy
Yarrow in his confession told how he
had unsuccessfully courted the young
Bible teacher in the small New Jer
sey town, had been spurned on every
occasion and finally, driven to despera
tion, had lured her into his car for
her last earthly ride. Following one
of the most ghastly crimes in his
tory, Yarrow told of burning his auto
mobile early the next morning to de
stroy telltale evidence. Police are
now investigating another phase of
the “hard luck” history of this con
temptible youth. His wife disappeared
two years ago and has never been
heard from since. Police believe she
may have suffered the fate of his
latest victim.
If Yarrow has had what he terms
hard luck in the past it is nothing to
what is coming to him in the future
when New Jersey's famous "quick
justice” begins to operate. Criminals
of his type—the type who are bestial
with women—are almost certain to
blubber some story of bad breaks
when they are confronted with re
sponsibility for their acts. Consequent
ly. Yarrow will only have to sob about
one more piece of hard luck and that
very probably will be when he Is led
to meet his death.
New Jersey admits no obligation to
solve one homicide mystery l>efore
agitating public attention with an
other.
No More Worlds.
Some twenty-three centuries ago
young Alexander, son of Philip of
Macedon and afterward known ns
"The Great,” complained bitterly: "My
father will leave me nothing to do."
A few days ago in Oslo, Norway,
Capt. Roald Amundsen lamented,
“There is nothing more for me to do.’’
Young Alexander gave voice to hia
fears as a youth, and before he was
to become master of Asia or cut a
bloody road into far-away, unknown
India. Amundsen's words were retro
spective, looking back over a rugged
J life which saw him achieve the North
, west Passage, encompass mountains
of ice on a march to the South Pole
and fly in a dirigible over the North
Pole. Alexander, the youth, with his
life before him, worried lest his father
had already set out the stakes hound
. ing the limits of any man’s life.
, Amundsen has done what no man did
before. Now there is nothing more
. for him to do.
Could Alexander return from "be
, yond the paths of the utmost sun” to
. gaze upon the worlds he conquered.
, how trivial they would appear and
. how puny his efforts seem! And if
r Capt. Amundsen is spared to spend
the twilight years of .1 brave and
active life in watching those who fol
. low the paths he blazed, how he will
I wonder at the nund»er of feet to tread
- them. Alexander died three hundred
> years before Christ was born, and
today the story of his youthful fears
1 still lives because it seems, in the
> hght es all that has happened since,
THE EVENING STAR. WASHINGTON, T). C., TUESDAY, OCTOBER' 4, 1927.
so absurd, so clearly indicative of the
narrow confines of the universe he
knew. But he still expresses the
doubtful attitude of the youth today,
who, looking about him at all the
wondrous things he sees, must feel
that he was born too late; that all
that was to he done has been done,
and there Is nothing more to do.
Nothing more to do! Amundsen
knew the heat of the flame that
burned in Alexander’s soul; that has
made torches of the lives of thousands
of brave men. lighting dark places
that others might follow them. Today
the flame burns as brightly as ever.
It is carried like a torch through the
skies. In the laboratories it Is show
ing the way to things never dreamed
of before, unfolding the mysterious
wonders of what lie under the sea,
under the earth and in the air we
breathe. In gatherings of men it Is
indicating, only faintly, It Is true, how
humans will shSre their lives together
in the years that are to come. So
long ns men are born, this spark will
live, bursting into flame now and then
in those who are destined to carry it.
When the spark dies, when the flame
no longer shines, then the puzzled
youth may conjure up the shades of
Alexander to mourn with him. Then,
It Is true, there will be nothing more
to do.
—■ > <
John Dalzell.
Nearly half a generation has passed
since John Dalzell left public life, re
tiring from his post in the House of
Representatives in consequence of the
political overturn which resulted from
the Republican divisions of 1012. He
had been a member of the lower
branch of Congress for a quarter of
a century continuously and hat.- be
come one of the foremost figures
the Nations.! Legislature. A hard work
er he wen rank in the organisa
tion of the House. Ke became one of
the leaders of his party in the cham
ber, rankfng with Cannon, Payne and
Dlngley during the period when im
portant fiscal questions were under
consideration. There were two sub
jects upon which Mr. Dalzell special
ized. the tariff and the rules of the
House. He was deeply versed In both.
An ardent supporter of the policy of
protection, he was ranked as a "stand
patter” and was constantly the target
of the attack of the opposition, both
Democratic and Republican. His in
timate knowledge of the rules of pro
cedure gave him a tactical .advantage
In his service in behalf of the econom
ic principles which he had espoused
and which he stoutly defended and
advanced. A man of high nervous
energy, indefatigable in his service,
unsparing of his forces, adept in de
bate and despite partisan differences
always commanding the respect and
esteem of the membership of the
House, Mr. Dalzell was for more than
a decade one of the most influential
factors in the national legislation.
Since his defeat for re-election in 1912
he has remained out of public view.
Personal sorrow lessened his inter
est in political affairs. He became al
most a recluse, and now at the age
of elghty-two he has passed, to many
a vivid memory of a remarkably ac
tive and valuable public service, cut
short by political mischance; to a
greater number, owing to the lapse
of years, merely the name of a once
noted personage.
A national party convention has
its undeveloped resources. A financial
genius, like Mr. Rickard, could easily
show how to clean up a few millions
on acreage sales of ringside seats.
. ■— i -■ - - -
Discoveries of ancient cities have
contributed not much to modem
science. They have been chiefly im
portant in impressing the fact that
all mummies look pretty much alike.
• »
There may be professional jealousy
even In patriotism. Mussolini has
never selected an understudy to take
up the work when ho passes.
East Indian princes show wealth
that Is dazzling. Yet it conveys little
moro public influence than the display
In a jewelry store window.
Admirers of Gov. A1 Smith have
established a reliable rule: "When
in doubt play ‘The Sidewalks of New
York.’ ”
SHOOTING STABS.
BY PHILANDER JOHNSON.
Shifted Responsibility.
"Somebody Else” Is a very good friend
As sorrows come hastening by.
Without hesitation, to him we extend
The blame when events go awry.
“Who was the weakling?” and "Who
was the knave?"
That shattered the hope which was
fair.
Poor "Somebody Else,” ever patient
and brave,
The brunt of the burden must bear.
Unlnterestingness.
"I w-ent to a banquet where there
were no speeches,” remarked Senator
Sorghum.
"Was it a relief?"
"No. Speeches would have lulled
me to sleep. The jazz band kept me
awake."
Natural History-
Explorers bold a point discuss
Where Nature seemed to slip.
The thirsty hippopotamus
Hath nothing on his hip.
End of Fairy Ijotr.
"I will grant you three wishes,” said
the fairy.
“If you oan do anything like that,”
said the business man, "let's incor
porate and hire salesmen."
Jazxifl cation.
I cannot sing the songs of long ago;
The skill, alas! I lack it;
So from the wall I take the old banjo
And merely raise a racket.
"We love dumb animals,” said Hi
Ho, the sage of China, "because they
can never talk and betray us.”
Anatomical Observation.
The beauty contest I should see
With rather more contented glee
If when my eyes the winners strike
They did not look so mu oh alike.

I THIS AND THAT |
BV CHARLES E. TRACEWELL.
Those who have set themselves up
to exalt the city man or woman at the
expense of their country cousins are
"biting off more than they can chew,”
In the homely language of the great
agricultural districts.
When the smart-alec boys have lam
pooned them to the limit of smart
alecdom’s vocabulary, the country
people will continue on their undis
turbed way, because, forsooth, they
do not often read the aforementioned
wisecrackers and would not be much
disturbed if they did.
We who also live in the cities but
take no especial childish pride In it
continue to harbor in our hearts a
large and genuine admiration for the
good folk of farm and field, of cross
roads and country town.
Without them, sure enough, there
would be no cities, and likewise there
would he no group of persons to turn
our roving thoughts back to the es
sentials now and then when we lose
our perspective and begin to feel that
the discovery of a new eating place
or the purchase of a new song by a
popular composer is on a par with
Columbus’ well known feat or the
writing of the ‘'Largo” by Handel.
** * *
Country people who come into our
city alley bring with them more than
fresh vegetables; they renew our faith
In human beings. Not that they are
faultless or any different from any
one else. That is the very point.
They are so like us at all points thnt
wo get a new evaluation from the
very contact with them.
There is a danger in city life which
the members of the so-called intelli
gentsia have allowed to run away with
them which would place the emphasis
on the thing of the moment rather
than upon trueness or any other
quality of permanence. The impor
tant thing from the rtar.dpo.nt of hu
manity in not that a man, wear the
'.atort .a cravats, but that h.& noon, be
.a the r.gfct plane.
Tr.o> c-v/ man. of *ourpo, may be
de.eo up to tie »Lnute ana ve
hioo a Made grdtp of maLty ana a
keen unocrotaxamg of h.s out / to
others. Th.r m a prerogative oi hu
manity, not depending upon mud on
the shoes or the lack of the same.
Richard Harding Davis in his “Van
Bibber” stories presented an engag
ing picture of a young and wealthy
man who had his heart In the right
place, despite his evening dress.
On the other hand, a countryman
may he more selfish than the chap
from the cities, with less of a sense of
humor, utterly unmeriting any praise.
So the matter Cannes down to this: It
is neither city nor country that
count, but the way one thinks.
** * *
In the main, however, it can be
stated with some truth- that country
people come nearer to driving super
ficiality out of their lives than city
folk. If this comes about partly be
cause of lack of opportunity, it can
not take away from them the credit.
One might say that a combined
bridge and gossip party in the city is
no whit different from a similar gath
ering for quilting and gossiping in the
country, but our answer would be
that in the former case the residue
is only debts, whereas in the latter
some serviceable quilts result for daily
use.
A similar comparison carried
through the life of country people
versus city people perhaps would
| BACKGROUND OF EVENTS |
BY PAUL V. COLLINS.
PARIS, France.
One would not expect to discover
unearthly weirdness in art by picking
up a trail in the Galerie du Louvre, j
still less from such a starting point
a copy of the famous and sweetly i
human picture by Mme. La Brun, de- i
picting herself and little daughter in
loving embrace.
Sauntering through the gallery, re
calling masterpieces enjoyed in the
long ago. I was attracted by the srupe
riority of the work of an artist who
was copying the Le Brun masterpiece.
Speaking in English, I oomplimentcd
the artist.
“How did you know that I could
speak English? I am a Frenchman,”
he replied, with a friendly twinkle in
his eyes. “I have my American wife
to thank for my English without a
French accent,” he explained. “I
lived in Canada several years, and
then in New York, where I took out
my first papers to become an Ameri
can citizen, but I am still here in
Prance. I see you're a Legionnaire,”
he continued. "I am entitled to the
Legion badge, like you wear. I served
four years as interpreter during the
war—nearly two years in the Ameri
can Army.”
He gave me his card—L. Theo
Dube, a pupil of (Jerome at the Na
tional School of Fine Arts (Beaux
Art!*)-
** * *
Upon invitation, I visited his home
the following day, where I found not
only a large collection of his own
paintings but an original Paul Vero
nese, a I>aubigny, a Rosa Bonheur
and other masterpieces. Showing a
list of his American patrons, »I. Dube
said that he had his portraits and
paintings in 105 cities of the United
States.
In reply to an Inquiry as to art in
France today, M. Dube said that the
art schools were flourishing, as usual,
except that the Ecole Nationale des
Beaux Arts is in a row over the Prix
de Rome. The prize was not given
this year because none of the works
submitted by the candidates was
counted worthy of that honor. The
contestants became angry and with
drew their pictures before the time
required for their exhibition, and that
angered the Jury.
”1 believe that art students of to
day,” remarked M. Dube, “have lost
appreciation of the real qualities of
art.”
As explained by M. Dube, each year
the students of the different art
classes, to the total of 300 contestants,
are selected by a jury to try for the
Prix de Rome. The winner has all
his expenses paid by the French gov
ernment for four years’ study in
Rome, and afterward for four years
while he Is establishing himself as an
artist in France.
The 300 contestants are cnflned in
separate studios for two hours, within
which time, without models, they
must produce a painting <lB by 22
inches) of a theme assigned to all
alike. Out of the number 30 of the
host are given an opportunity to enter
a second contest, without models. Out
of the 30 the best 10 are then per
mitted to use models and paint their
final pictures (alx»ut 48 by 60 inches)
within three months, these being en
largements of the original small com
positions. No material change from
the original small pictures is per
mitted in the final paintings. These
contests have been maintained for
many years.
It was a rare prlvelege, secured
through M. Dube's influence, that the
doors of the Ecole Nationale des
Beaux Arts were opened for my In
spection of the paintings in previous
contests. Rarely has a winner of a
Prix de Rome failed to become Justly
famous.
“If art achievement Is found un
worthy today,” said M. Dube, “it Is
because the students have liecome
confused by modern fads, including
impressionism.”
When asked his opinion regarding
the Monet and Manet school of im
pressionism and that of the cubists
and post-cubists and the works of
Pissaro and Cezanne, he replied that
he referred particularly to the Monet-
Manet impressionism.
“DM you know,” fi», asked, “that
.palate* 4* ">d*Ce.
show a similar credit to the ledger of
the former, not because they are es
sentially any different sort of per
sons, hut largely because circum
stances force them to live nearer to
essential realities.
City life is, In fact, an attempted
escape from much of the hard reality
of country living, with its incessant
chores, its lack of modern facilities
for comfort in many cases and its
deep brooding monotony. Inventions
of various sorts have come to invade
these ancient drawbacks of the farm,
but so long as country boys come to
the large cities In droves every year
the invasion cannot yet be said to be
entirely successful.
** * *
A drawback in our city life is that
it tends to develop smugness of mind,
than which no mental state is more
stultifying to the average human be
ing. Because one reads the American
Mercury and is familiar with the
tunes of George Gershwin does not
necessarily mean that he is a progres
sive being, although it may, of course.
There is in every large community
a certain number of persons who have
developed what might he called “clty
itis,” the symptoms of which are a
deep distrust in human beings, a
large suspicion of their fellow men.
Country persons are reasonably free
from this annoying disease. In every
1,000 persons, say, In a city there are
250 such sufferers, whereas in 1,000
country people only 50 will be dis
covered. The close crowding of the
cities has something to do with it,
there being a quality in the human
spirit which cannot tolerate hugger
mugger, but a larger reason Is the
city atmosphere tending toward lack
of friendliness. There is, too, so much
annual change jzt a city that neigh
bors do not get to know- each other
as do families that live in the same
places for many years, ever, many
gcr.erat.ons.
■a a + a
The g'na.r.f sour.i ry people who
rcir.o to our back doe? v. ft the prod
ucta of their vegetable patches meet
ur on tne plane of human be.ngr
where or.o l.acc to be met, w.th no
feeling of distrust on either aide
The old man with the white beard
talks of what he knows with no pre
tense to anything. He admires the
white rose in bloom, although in the
shade for the past month and a half,
as the sun In Its path across the
heavens deserted it until next year.
He asks If It is a tearose, and con
tinues with reminiscences of a small
hush of his own which he was unable
to make grow more than a foot high.
But last year he picked all the buds
off as they formed, so that during
September It glorified Itself with 70
full-blown blossoms at one time.
This, we agree, with much enthusi
asm, is quite a feat for a bush no
higher tha«> a foot. And to this the
old man replies with other interest
ing accounts of other of his plants.
AH this time the natural transac
tions of several quarts of stringed!
beans from his measure to our dish
has been In progress, with the result
ing and necessary' exohange of several
coins of the realm.
These contacts not only are pleas
ing In themselves, but they help one
to keep firmly in mind the sanity of
country people and their everyday
wholesomeness of character. Where
fore when we read some one who is
prating about tho glory of the “men
of the cities” we turn over the page.
studies of the Rheims Cathedral to
show the different effects of light—
blue shadows, purple shadows, etc.? I
j pay no attention to the cubists, or to
! Pissaro, or Cezanne —that’s just plain
j insanity; it doesn’t mean anything.
I “There is beauty in impressionism;
it vibrates,” said the artist. "Study
Winterhalter’s picture of Empress
Eugenie and her entourage. It is very
beautiful, but it lacks vibration. Win
terhalter avoided painting the Em
press as h>ng as he could, for he was
afraid that he could not satisfy her—
he could not make her as beautiful as
she was in life. Eugenie is certainly
pretty, but so are all her ladies in
waiting; there is absolutely no dis
tinction in values, absolutely no vi
bration of color. The impressionists
have taught how to make color vibrate
and sparkle, hut that is all. There Is
something else to be considered in
serious art.”
** # #
The visit at the Hrifce of M. Dube
brought the "surpri^o”—the "weird
surprise”—in two pictures by Augus
tin Lesage.
Augustin Lesage was a coal miner
until the psychic “voices” persisted in
speaking to him In the blackness of
the coal mines:
“Paint!”
“How can I paint? T am unedu
cated and have never learned how to
paint,” protested the begrimed miner.
“Paint!” insisted the “voices.”
He dropped his pick and went to the
art store at St. Omar and bought the
costjiest colors. He astounded the
artists, the art schools and the psychic
researchers with the amazing beauty
of his paintings.
M. Dube makes no eiTort to explain
the Lesage paintings. They are all
abstract designs, hut their exquisite
"patterns” are as beautiful as an
India shawl.
** # *
We visited the headquarters of the
Institut Metapsychique Internationale
in the palatial home of Dr. Ostry, its
secretary, where M. Dube had but re
cently hung the psychic pictures
which had so interested the members
of the institute. On September 26 the
institute opened its third international
conference on psychio research. Gru
zew'skl, the Polish painter “of the
soul,” w'as in attendance. The painter
claims that he does not do the actual
painting; it is the work of invisible
spirits.
Chabas, the artist made famous by
his picture "September Morn,” now
hanging in the Luxembourg Gallery,
posed for Gruzewskl, and was amazed
to see the sudden production of his
fMftrait and of the heads of several
“souls” behind him, all done In 30
minutes, with startling realism.
Gruzewskl’s pictures are not
sketches, but are modeled paintings
or pastels, some with wonderful color,
all with devilish force, gripping weird
ness and complicated composition.

NEW BOOKS
AT RANDOM
I. G. M.
THE GRANDMOTHERS. Glenway
Wescott. Harper & Bros.
Two points of repulsion meet me at
the doorstep of "The Grandmothers.”
Both are worth a moment of atten
tion, partly because of the rare fact
that In this case they are so speedily
and thoroughly put to rout, partly be
cause the same two points work, as a
rule, against the full, general accept
ance of any fiction. This is a prize
novel—first count against it. As a
second adverse odds, it deals exclu
sively with a past lying so close to the
present as not to have acquired any
of the illusive and glamorous charm
of a real past.
About the first of these two: Men
are like pigs—they refuse to be driven.
They themselves are callable of lead
ing and directing, or so they think.
Even in a choice of reading they in
stinctively and secretly resent the
super and elect group sitting in judg
ment upon the work of competing
novelists. However, curiosity is nat
ural, just as rebellion against self
constituted authority is natural.
Therefore, a prize novel is often ac
cepted in a spirit of "We’ll see about
this ourselves.”
About the second of the two: The
mind moves forward for its satisfac
tions, not backward. It has to. Hope
Is the essence of all human, existence,
and that lies to the front in such
promise as we are able to invent for
it. Forward-looking fiction has an
enormous advantage over that which
deals with a past, so immediate as to
seem drear/ and ur.stirring.
Half-hearted in the face cf such
dear rebuff. I leaf the new' prise-win
ner without enthusiar.no. Dul. scuff,
it looks to be, coneo.-nad wholly w.'h
graaon*.others &RC. grir.dfithcrs, oea.-
ar.c. ‘great” ar.c great-groat,” w.:i
uncles &r.o aun s inn cousins of :.r.-
moc.a.lo ana iegroe Ana be
cauto '.no bock door n’t. putt n: nv>
itself, I ill. to th.nk*ns n* « .’self .n
like su.vour.a.r.ga—a. commonplace
unstirring element. Then the boy
telling hlB story catches my eye, tell
ing the story as his grandmother told
it to him. I wake up a bit right here
because —well, you 6ee, anybody’s
grandmother Is a priceless possession,
all the dearer, too, now that the tribe
has become utterlv extinct.
It is on the tide of this dear and
lost relationship, with all it connotes,
that I move into the rich domain of
Glenway Wescott’s big novel; that I
sense its deep importance and its
prime interest as a picture of the
American lifo that lies but a hand’s
throw behind us, its realities and sig
nificances rather generally neglected
for a more remote and more impressive
past, or for the forecastings of a more
brilliant tomorrow. Simple, full, com
plete is the story of this corner of
| Wisconsin. Taken up bodily, it might
1 bo set down in an exact pattern of
life in many parts of America at a
period corresponding to this one of
winning homes out of the forest lands
of this country. The story varies
with the outgoings and homecomings
of one another of this brood of rela
tions. Here from such a source
springs a picture of the Civil War,
and another of life farther on into the
West, and one of Europe brought
into this untamed spot by virtue of
the greater daring of one of the tribe.
All, however, home back to this Wis
consin. center, deepening its effect,
amplifying its promise, accenting the
daily features of its life within the
immediate past, explaining the qual
ity of much of our Americanism.
Yet this boy, listening to his grand
mother, recording, making sure of
every point In the daily existence and
j outlook of the people to whom he is
! related, for whom he Is speaking by
direct word of mouth —this boy is in
! finitely more than a faithful reporter.
A good deal of a seer, a good deal of
a poet, he adds to a scrupulous exacti
tude the gift of sympathetic insight
and illuminating interpretation. He
is original, both in thought and ex
pression. There are beautiful mo
ments in this story—moments that
have no tinge of the hackneyed or the
overdone to mar their effect. With a
theme that does not easily lend itself
to the requirements of drama, this
writer has, nevertheless, built a cumu
lative, tense, coherent story—a sterv
that deserves the distinction accorded
it; one that also deserves the wide
reading it is bound to have.
** * *
THE GLORIOUS ADVENTURE.
Richard Halliburton. The Hobbs-
Merrill Co.
My first and last reaction to "The
Glorious Adventure” is envy. I envy
Richard Halliburton his youth, his
spirit of romance, his zest of life, the
royal adventure that he put 3 through.
I envy him his father nightly cradling
the hoy with tales of old Greeks and
the Trojan War and mightier men
than time has since been able to pro
duce. I even env’y him the schooling
that failed to shape him to the univer
sity pattern. It is a stirring thing,
this story of personal adventure. I
leave It to you. Here is a youth, all
schooled and fixed up and finished,
ready, presumably, to step into the
field of useful things, an instrument
of service and the rest of it. And
what does this youth do to fulfill the
sterling hopes of his community in
respect to himself? Why, he sets off
upon the most original of adventures,
nothing less than following the course
of old Ulysses in his 10-year Odyssey
of trying to get back home to Penel
ope after having fought so gloriously
in the Trojan War. Ulysses is pecul
iarly modern, a fine man to follow
today. He is, moreover, the classic
example of getting around the old
fact of not being able to eat your cake
and have it too. Ulysses fought glori
ously—a wonderful mouthful of cake,
that, for this fighting man. Then,
with the kindly aid of tempests and
tides and currents, he was for long
years constrained from getting hack
home to Penelope, weaving by day
and raveling by nisht to stave off the
suitors banked around her. Mean
while, Ulysses was meeting Circe and
the Sirens, was loafing, half asleep,
around the Lotus Land. When at last
he did make shift to get home he had
the delight of slaughtering Penelope’s
young men, of retaking the faithful
Penelope herself. A clear and rounded
case, you see, of gorging on cake and
then miraculously of finding it fresh
and unbitten right in front —of
Ulysses. A good man to follow', any
way you take him. So Richard Halli
burton. with Koderic Crane along,
mapped the course of Ulysses and fol
lowed it—the literal geographic course,
not the one having to do with Sirens
and such. And the amazing things
that in the sheer lust of life this
young fellow did! Like Byron and
Leander, he swam the Hellespont, he
ran the Marathon over the original
course, he climbed the walls of the
Acropolis in the moonlight, he hunted
the Sirens in the eaves of Capri, he
definitely trailed Ulysses with old
Homer as a guide, finding the Lotus
Land. He did it all. But here is one
departure from Ulysses, a beautiful
departure—he made a pilgrimage to
the grave of Rupert Brooke, buried
on the lonely Island of Skyros. Here
you weep—l think he is weeping, too
—over the lost youth, the lost genius
that is Rupert Brooke. Then away
in the company of dryads and Pan.
They look like modern Greek girls and
a beautiful Greek hoy to us, reading:
hut, of course, they are dryads and
tho little pagan god himself. Oh, well,
it is a rare adventure, really "glori
ous.” just as Halliburton says it is!
And to an amazing degree has he
captured it whole in body and spirit
to set down in a book for your read
ing and mine. You, too, are bound to
envv this boy—for his youth, and his
high spirit, and for the romantic ad
venture which h« dared to pursue and

PHILOSOPHIES
BY
GLENN FRANK
J.ast year the mind of the Nation
was shocked by what seemed a viru
lent epidemic of suicide among the
young.
The other day a big life insurance
company published the results of a
statistical study of suicide in the
United States over a period of 15
years.
This study Indicates that the death
rate from suiside at all ages has been
; steadily dec lining in the United States,
nnd that suicide among the young has
been decreasing most rapidly.
Tho age group from 10 to 19 shows
the greatest decrease.
The age group from 20 to 29 shows
the second greatest decrease.
The age group from 30 to 59 shows ;
the third greatest decrease.
The age group from CO on shows the
least decrease.
A few months ago, while preparing
a magazine article on student suicides,
I waded through a mass of vital statis
tics and various studies to determine
what research had established to date
respecting suicide. The following
things seem fairly well established:
First, the proportion of male to fe
male suicides remained virtually the
same for many years, only one out of
every four suicides being a woman,
but lately suicide among women has
been increasing.
Second, the number of suicides in
creases month by month from Janu- i
ary to June, the maximum being i
reached usually in May or June.
Third, suicides are more frequent in j
Summer than in Winter, in fair j
weather than in foul, in pence than
in war, in prosperity than in poverty, j
Fourth, some professions consist- 1
ently contribute more suicides to the ,
death list than others, and the rela-;
tivo frequency of suicide among per- j
sons in different professions and em
ployments remains roughly the same
year after year.
Fifth, suicide is commoner among ;
Protestants than among Roman Path
olios, but even less among Jews than
among Roman Catholics.
Sixth, suicid® is commoner among |
tho educated than among the illiterate |
classes.
Seventh, suicide is commoner in i
cities than in the country.
Eighth, suicide bears a definite and
fairly predictable relation to age.
Ninth, the suicide rate has been dis
covered, in several studies, to be twice
as high among unemployed as among
employed men.
Tenth. It is possible to establish def
inite suicide rates for different coun
tries. and while the suicide rate of any
given country may Charfge from year
to year, its relative proportion to the
suicide rate of other countries will
stay virtually the same year after
year.
Suicide is a baffling problem, but.
like other problems, it must be first
approached by careful scientific search
for eauses; a blind branding of any
thing we may happen to dislike In
school or church or state as the root
causa of Aiieide waves is irrational
and ineffective.

matter of course, but any question of
discipline must depend on what the
inquiry shows,” according to the Buf
falo Evening News, which finds a
"sensible attitud* taken by Secretary
Wilbur." The South Bend Tribune t
observes that "Secretary Wilbur
emerges from the afTalr with most of
the honors,” and the Kansas City Post
concludes that "if all department
heads would behave in a similar man
ner, half the objection to bureaucratic
administration would become invalid.”
The Indianapolis News interprets ths
"disposition to accept the suggestions
i in good spirit” as possibly meaning
that "the Secretary will welcome an
investigation.”
"Admiral Magruder has expressed
himself, not recklessly and loosely,
but with logical argument supported
by evidence,” comments the Worcester
Telegram, and the Jersey City Journal
states: "Nine out of ten people prob
ably agree with the admiral as a mat
ter of principle established by long •
experience with official expenditures
and extravagance. This, in the public
mind, puts the burden of proof, not
on the admiral to demonstrate he is
right, but on the Secretary to demon
strate that the admiral is wrong.”’
** * *
“If the criticisms are weil founded,”
! declares the Philadelphia Publio
• Ledger, “it is well to have them pub
! lie and in the open. It may be that
j Admiral Magruder will be subjected
| to departmental discipline for them.
[ That is the risk he took, and It is
| scarcely conceivable that he took il
! blindly.” The Oklahoma City Okla
. homan remarks that “it may be that
I the answer will be the ancient answer
i of bureaucrats —a disciplinary order
stopping the mouth of the trouble-
I some admiral.” #
“His good faith is unquestionable,"
in the judgment of the St. Paul Pio
neer Press, and tho Lexington Leader
I says that “If only by giving publicity
i to the facts as he describes them can
j the corrective Le supplied, he is justi-
I tied in writing as he has.” The Hart
ford Times feels that “no one would
doubt very much that the Navy la
overoffleered, and that it has as much
red tape as rigging on its ships.”
Recognizing that "in times of peace !<
is quite easy for departments relating
to war to stagnate,” the Charleston
Daily Mall holds that “initiative does
not know whether it will be welcomed
or frowned upon.”
Secretary Wilbur’s order is ap- »,
praised by the Baltimore Sun as show
ing “a distorted sense ot humor,”
while the New York World is of tho
opinion that the Secretary “thul
places on the admiral a responsibility
that might well have been assumed
by others on duty at Washington.”
On the other hand, the Reno Evening
Gazette asserts that “the admiral, dis
tinguished in two wars, famous foi
his personal bravery, survivor of two
wrecks and come of a family of noted
soldiersand sailors, should not havd

Miss Cowles *
Will Marry
Mr. Black
At a party given yesterday in
Princeton, N. J., at the home ol
Mrs. John Pearce, the announce
ment was made of the engage
ment of Miss Nancy Carson
Cowles to Mr. William Heath
Black. Miss Cowles is the daugh
ter of CoL Miles Andrew Cowles,
the Military Attache of the United
States Legation in Bern, Switzer
land, and Mrs. Cowles. Mr. Black
is the son of Mr. Eugene R. Black,
president of the International
Bank for Reconstruction and De
velopment, and Mrs. Black.
The bride-elect received her
education at Miss Fine’s School
In Princeton and Abbott Acad
emy In Andover, Mass. She was
graduated from the Ecole Inter
nationale in Geneva, Switzerland,
and later attended the Univer
sity- of Geneva and the Sorbonne
in Paris. At present. Miss Cowles
is a student at the Connecticut
College for Women in New Lon
don.
Mr. Black is a graduate of the
Lawrenceville School in Law
renceville, N. J., and is presently
in his junior year at Yale Uni
versity where he is a resident of
Calhoun College and a member
of the Pence Club. He is the
grandson of the late Mr. William
Pratt Heath and Mrs. Heath of
Atlanta and of the late Mr. Eu
gene Robert Black, former chair
man of the Board of Governors
of the Federal Reserve Bank, and
Mrs. Black.
Exclusively Yours
Washington Stacks Up Well Against European Capitals;
Guests at State Dinner Throw Protocol to the Winds
Home—after six weeks in Eu
rope—looks good. The Conti
nent has much to offer that is
beautiful, strange and some
times heady, but Washington
still stacks up very well. Over
there they look upon the United
States Capital as the place
where the plays are called for
the free world, and some of
them would give an eye tooth
to be here.
Paris, though, is still the
most excitingly beautiful city
of all. Was it Bismarck who
once said that Paris must have
the best climate in the world—
no diplomat had ever asked to
be recalled from there for rea
sons of health?
Actually, its climate is its
worst feature, unless you want
to give its current cost of living
that dubious honor. Whereas
Paris formerly offered all this
and heaven too on a compara
tively low budget, it’s now as
expensive, they say, as New
York. Rents are high, food is
high and only millionaires can
afford its couturiers’ fashions,
and even a good copiste costs
between one and two hundred
dollars. Divine clothes in Italy
cost less and in Spain much
less. A man can get a good
tailor-made suit in Madrid for
$45: a woman, a designer’s tail
leur for SIOO.
Prices will scare some people
away from Paris next year, but
travelers will always flock from
all points of the globe if only for
a sniff of its free air. Next to
its beauty, the most noticeable
difference between Paris and
other European and American
cities is its uninhibited, uncon
ventional atmosphere. Fantas
tically garbed people walk its
streets and nobody thinks it
strange. Lovers pause in the
middle of a boulevard to kiss
and no eyebrows are raised.
New Precedent
Set ot Dinner
A new precedent was set at a
formal state dinner in Washing
ton the other evening all be
cause of this modern technolog
ical age. It was at the party
the Norwegian Ambassador and
Mms. Morgenstierne gave for
cocktails in the lounge
dancing from 5:30 p.m. 'till closing
the deMarlos
cptate exotic atmosphere 6:30
and 11 p.m.

MISS NANCY CARSON COWLES
Engaged to
Mr. William Heath Black.
By Betty Beole
Norwegian Prime Minister Torp.
Loaded with rank, everything
went strictly according to pro
tocol until just before the des
sert course. As the hour pushed
9:30, hints were dropped that
Vice Presidential Candidate
Nixon was about to go on the
air. The host became aware
that some, but maybe not the
highest ranking people, sur
rounding his table were eager to
hear the speech even though din
ner was still being served by
white-gloved waiters. Secretary
of State Acheson was the rank
ing American present but he
could hardly suggest an exodus
for a purpose that might not in
terest the foreign guest of
honor. It was a ticklish proto
col problem.
Finally the ladies* comments
thrust a decision to the fore.
Chief of Protocol Jack Simmons
spoke to Secretary Acheson, Am
bassador Morgenstierne looked
at Acheson, the Prime Minister
looked at Morgenstierne and in
the nick of time the host stood
up and said that every one could
carry his dessert into the draw
ing room to watch TV. The
unprecedented switch from stiff
formality to plate-carrying style
made such a hit that the guests
not only listened to Nixon but
they stayed glued to TV for the
next half hour to hear Gov. Ste
venson.
Striped Bass
Fishermen
The Thomas Adams have
returned from Falmouth, Mass.,
bearing certificates from the
Field and Stream magazine,
buttons and whatnot, and Nancy
and Tom Clagett will arrive in
similar fashion when they check
into town November 1. The
reason is that both couples are
now veteran striped bass fisher
men off famed Cuttyhunk Island.
Twice this past summer the
Clagetts left the lush confines
of fashionable Newport, took
to their yacht and sailed down
to Cape Cod to pick up Caroline
and Tommy. From there they
went to Cuttyhunk, the smallest
of the Elizabeth Islands off the
Cape and the antithesis of New
port. It boasts all of 70 dwell
ings probably counting the
chicken houses, and three vin
tage automobiles plus three tele
phones. The Clagetts and
Adamses put up at one of the
only two boarding houses and
ate at the same community
table with three sugar planters
from Puerto Rico.
Come 6:30 in the evening they
piled into two 18-foot boats, each
with a guide, and headed for
the dark inlets where they fished
until 1,2, 3 or 4 in the morn
ing. That’s the usual routine.
When they returned to the
boarding house hot coffee was
always waiting. All brought
home the bacon, as it were.
Caroline hooked two 40 pound
ers. The island record, rarely
approached, is 73 pounds. Dur
ing the daytime they had a
first-rate floor show to watch.
Navy bombers from Quonset
regularly came over to bomb
nearby target islands with live
rockets. •
The Clagetts are not ooming
down from Newport until the
first of November because their
Chevy Chase house is not yet
entirely built. After seeing the
Wiley Buchanans’ new wing last
spring, they decided to enlarge
their own domicile Instead of
getting a new one. By the time
It’s completed only the facade
and the living room will remain
unchanged.

Viet Nam Ambassador
To Move This Week
Greek Envoy on Trip to West Coast;
Brazilian Minister Arriving Soon
By Katharine M. Brooks
Viet Nam Ambassador and Mme.
Tran Van Kha will move the
middle of the week from their
apartment in the Shoreham to the
house at 3312 Woodley road which
they have leased. The Chancery
of the Embassy also will be estab
lished at the new address.
The Ambassador and his wife
recently returned from a hurried
visit in their homeland. They went
back after the diplomat presented
his credentials and was received
in July by the President, to tell
the Foreign Office of their needs
in this Capital.
The house has been a popular
spot for delightful small and in
formal parties given there by Ad
miral Sir Cyril Douglas-Pennant
when he was chief of the Naval
Staff of the British Joint Mission.
Since he went home in the sum
mer the house has been empty.
Well-Known Neighbors
Neighbors of the Ambassador
and Mme. Tran Van Kha in their
new abode will include Mr. andi
Mrs. Alexander Cretziano, son and
daughter-in-law of former Ru
manian Minister Georges Cret
ziano. The late former Minister
was accredited to this Capital
from 1926 to 1929 and was one
of the most popular hosts in the
diplomatic corps. Mr. Alexander
Cretziano also served his govern
ment in its diplomatic posts and
was chief of the mission in
Turkey before coming to this
country to live.
Retired Maj. Gen. Amos A. Fries,
chief of Chemical Warfare during
World War I, and Mrs. Fries also
are near neighbors. Their daugh
ter Betsy, now Mrs. John Shirley
Hurst, is in Formosa where Mr.
Hurst is chief of public relations
for the Mutual Security Agency.
They plan to spend Christmas
with a group of others from this
conutry on duty in that vicinity
and will meet in Hong Kong.
Greek Envoy Leaving
Greek Ambassador Athanase
Politis has started on his trip
to the West Coast. He is going to
attend the 11th assembly of the
Greek Orthodox Church in Los
Angeles. This meeting also will
include the consecration of the
new Greek Orthodox Church
which has been built at a cost of
$1.5 million. It is of Byzantine
design and both the interior and
exterior are of great beauty. The
dedication is set for October 2.
The Ambassador will go on to
Mexico City following the dedi
cation and the assembly meetings.
Mexico also is Included in the
diplomat’s assignment and while
in the VMexican capital he will
present his credentials and be re
ceived by the President. The envoy
will be back the latter part of
October.
Brazilian Visitor Coming
The Minister of the Brazilian
Marines, Vice Admiral Renate de
Almeida Guillobel, will be in
Washington for a visit next week.
He will be the guest In whose
honor the Ambassador, Mr. Wal
ther Moreira Salles, will enter
tain at a reception October 8
from 6 to 8 o’clock.
Another visitor from Brazil Is
the Chief of the Air Force, Maj.
Gen. Vasco Alves Secco, who was
here for a day or so earlier this
month and is making a tour of air
bases and fields in this country.
Maj. Gen. Secco came here at the
invitation of the United States
Air Force. He will return to Wash
ington Friday and Saturday eve
ning will be the guest of honor
of the Air Attache of the Embassy,
Brig. Gen. Luis Netto dos Reys,
who will entertain at dinner.
Gen. Secco will give a reception
October 6 at the Army Navy Coun
try Club when his guest of honor
will be the Chief of Staff of the
United States Air Force, Gen.
Hoyt S. Vandenberg.

THE BOOTERY shoes In Arlington ot L FRANK CO.
Miss Landry
Is Engaged
Announcement is made by Mr.
and Mrs. Robert G. Landry of
Bethesda of the engagement of
their daughter Sara Yvonne to
Mr. James Elliott Mooney, jr., of
Atlanta, Ga. He is the son of Dr.
and Mrs. Mooney of Arlington and
St. Petersburg, Fla.
Miss Landry attended Chevy
Chase Junior College and George
Washington University. She is
presently a member of the staff
of Senator Taft. Her fiance
studied at the University of
Tampa and was graduated from
the University of Florida where
he continued his graduate work.
Mr. Mooney also attended the
University of North Carolina and
Mercer University. During the
last war he served in the Naval
Air Corps and he is a member of
Sigma Chi fraternity.
The wedding will take place
later this fall.
Dean-Bolian
Announcement
The marriage, of Miss Doris
Bolian to Mr. Charles H. Dean, jr..
took place at the National Baptist
Memorial Church on September 27,
with Dr. Edward B. Willingham
officiating. Following the cere
mony, a reception was given by
Mr. and Mrs. Gordon D. Fox at
their home in Chevy Chase.
Miss Ella Mae North was the
bride’s attendant and Mr. Ben
Tucker Dean served his brother
as best man. The bride is the
daughter of Mr. Sam Bolian of
Brookhaven, Miss., and Mr. Dean
is the son of Mr. and Mis. Her
mon Dean of Canton, Miss.
After a wedding trip to the East,
Mr. and Mrs. Dean will reside in
Jackson, Miss., where he is prac
ticing architecture.

THE SUNDAY STAR
Washington. D. C.
SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER XS. 19#*
Clifton-De Luca
Announcement
Announcement is made of the
engagement of Miss Doreen Louisa
Clifton, daughter of Mrs. Flora L
Clifton of Wellington and the late
Mr. Daniel McK. Clifton of Nova
Scotia and Montreal, to Mr. John
F. De Luca. He is the son of Mr.
and Mrs. P. De Luca of New Haven,
Conn.
Miss Clifton is an accountant at
the British Embassy and her fi
ance was graduated from the
Medicine. He plans to continue his
studies at Yale University and he
is a member of the Beta Chi Chap
ter of Alpha Sigma Chi.
The marriage will take place on
November 29.
